description:
This is the first meetup aimed at beginners learning to code and develop software. The format will be:

Scheduled talks (~20mins each)

Why I Code - by Paul Nelligan who is, amongst other things, the sole founder AND developer for audiofu.com, an organizer of Berlin Skills Exchange (http://www.meetup.com/Berlin-Skills-Exchange/ and the person who built the official Google Chrome App for Euro 2012! He is also working on side projects and does contracting.

Behind the Scenes of a Web Request - by Duana Stanley who works as a Backend Engineer at SoundCloud after moving from Australia where she worked for some years as a Software Engineer doing Java in small and large organisations. She hacks with ruby/rails and javascript for fun side projects.

Learn-n-Tell

Inspired from Berlin's wonderful Hack-n-Tell (http://www.meetup.com/berlin-hack-and-tell) session, this is a chance for you to share with others what you have learnt, what code you have written, some questions you have (there are no stupid questions!) or something you are stuck on. You don't have to prepare - all you need is 5 minutes! So bring your laptop - who knows - maybe there is something you have learnt that is really helpful for others.
how_to_find_us: Nearest U-Bahn is Kotbusser Tor. The entrance is through the yard and the building at the back right.
name: First Beginners Meetup!

description:
Please join us for an introduction to Python using PythonTurtle, followed by more Python workshops with other themes and exercises (to be announced soon). We will be holding an optional installation party on August 31st at 19:00 (also at co.up) to get everything set up for the following day. You will need to bring your own laptop in order to participate.

The space is wheelchair accessible; please call the mobile number posted at the door so we can send down the elevator for you. If you have any special needs, please don't hesitate to let us know.

Because the number of seats is limited, it is important that you only sign up if you definitely plan on coming (and do so, too!). If you can't make it for any reason, please cancel your attendance on Meetup right away so your someone on the waiting list can take your place. Thanks!
how_to_find_us: co-up.de/about.html#location We will be in the downstairs space, so please ring at co.up 3.OG and come up to the 4th floor (also wheelchair accessible).
name: Introduction to programming with python

description:
This is a meetup aimed at beginners learning to code and develop software.

 

Questions or proposals for talks? Write us at http://goo.gl/mod/yJ75

 

The format of our September meetup will be:

Scheduled talks (~20mins each)

#Cooking Software 101 - by Pere Urbón Bayes

What is the difference between cooking and making software? In this
talk we're going to learn the process of cooking software. From
Leibniz [3], Hilbert until Turing [4], the solution of
Entscheidungsproblem [2] develop something called Algorithms [1] and
the first machineries that nowadays we've in our hands, but we need
the basics to make them work.

Through examples we're going to learn the basics that enable us to
create elegant, readable and efficient solutions. We'll also learn how
to sort, search, iterate and recurs methods. At the end of this talk
you'll have an introduction to the necessary resources to develop
software with any programming language.

So what's the difference between cooking and making software?

[1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithm
[2] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entscheidungsproblem
[3] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gottfried_Leibniz
[4] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Turing

 

# Web Standards 101 - by Simon

Web standards are technologies like HTML, CSS and JavaScript. Together, they are the basic building blocks of any website or web application.
A short introduction on why web standards matter, how those technologies work together, and how to use them.

 

Learn-n-Tell

Inspired from Berlin's wonderful Hack-n-Tell (http://www.meetup.com/berlin-hack-and-tell) session, this is a chance for you to share with others what you have learnt, what code you have written, some questions you have (there are no stupid questions!) or something you are stuck on. You don't have to prepare - all you need is 5 minutes! So bring your laptop - who knows - maybe there is something you have learnt that is really helpful for others.
name: Beginners Meetup

description:
This is the second workshop in the ongoing "Learning to program with Python" series. This time we'll code our very first Twitter client (reading tweets from OpenTechSchool) and look into a few new types (dicts and lists).

This workshop will span approximately 2 hours and will take place on the lower floor of co.up. It does not require more knowledge about python or programming than what you've learnt in the "Introduction to programming with Python".
how_to_find_us: co-up.de/about.html#location We will be in the DOWNSTAIRS space, so please ring at "co.up 3.OG" and come up to the 3rd floor. The space is wheelchair accessible; please let us know you're coming so we can send down the elevator for you!
name: Program your first Twitter client with Python

description:
This is a Meetup not only for learners, that already have taken a class at udacity.com, but everybody interested in learning with online classes. So if you are please feel invited for this event. Udacity.com is one of the websites that offers free online classes on subjects like programming, math, and physics.

The meetup will take place on the on September 15th from 14:00 to 17:00 at co.up (Adalbertstr. 7-8, 10999 Berlin), which is kindly providing the space.

Program

The Berlin edition of this meetup will have a very special guest: Professor Jörn Loviscach (http://www.j3l7h.de/). His Udacity class, "Differential Equations in Action (cs222). Making Math Matter" has just started. Loviscach will give a talk with the topic, "Udacity from the inside and the outside: profit from free education."

Further topics in the program:

* a discussion with professor Loviscach with questions and answers about Udacity, and the possibility to give feedback

* local learning initiatives will introduce their work: RailsGirls Berlin and OpenTechSchool

* you can introduce yourself to other participants of the meetup and find a learning group for the class you are currently taking or plan to take in the future

* you can give a lightning talk (5 minutes) on the (learning) subject you are interested in

name: Udacity Global Meetup supported by OpenTechSchool

This is our third meetup, aimed at beginners learning to code and develop software. The format of our October meetup will be:

Scheduled talks (~20mins each)

# Binary Switches 101 by Duana Stanley

There is either something, or nothing. There is something deeply philosophical about the fact that we can build any computational system based on this principle. Let's take a closer look at switches - the fundamental computing-machine "wonder-brick" that makes so much possible.

# Fiona lernt programmieren by @fotografiona

Fiona will talk about her experiences with learning to program and about her blog https://fionalerntprogrammieren.wordpress.com/. (more info soon)

description:
We decided to repeat the awesome "Javascript for Absolute Beginners" workshop we held back in June, with a slightly improved curriculum. If you are interested in learning Javascript, feel free to sign up for this weekend-long workshop!

All you need is a laptop, installation of <a>Chrome</a> and Sublime Text 2, and you are ready to go.

This workshop consists of a meet&greet/install party on Friday starting at 19:30 and the two-day workshop taking place Saturday and Sunday from 11:00 until approximately 17:00.

The workshop is free of charge. You are invited to bring some food to share. Drinks can be bought on site for 1€ per bottle.

If you have registered but can't make it to the workshop for any reason, please click that you are not coming on Meetup so your spot can go to someone else! Also, if the list is already full, sign up for the waiting list. Depending on the amount of coaches, we might gonna raise the participants we can take later...

description:
Enter the world of social coding with Git and GitHub! In this course we'll introduce you to GitHub, a free online service where over 2 million developers from around the world share their code. We'll show you how to share your code, meet like-minded programmers, and participate in other projects. You can even host simple websites using GitHub. Whether you just want to share a little script, connect with fellow programmers or contribute to some of the largest and most dynamic software projects in the world, we'll show you how to get started!

This course requires no previous knowledge of Git and is suitable for beginners of any programming language. No programming will be required during the course, but feel free to bring along your code for sharing on GitHub. You will need to bring your own laptop.

description:
This is our fourth meetup, aimed at beginners learning to code and develop software. The format of our October meetup will be:

Scheduled talks (~20mins each)

# A Coder's Life (So Far) by @stevenfarlie
Join Steven as he recounts his life in code. From beginnings on a farm in rural Australia through to consulting in some of the country's biggest websites.

# Lists list lists by Leonhard
Lists are everywhere: todos, recipes, plans, speech, programs, algorithms, Turing machines and even math can be expressed as lists. Leonhard will show you what the basic concept of a list is, how some well know subtypes (Arrays, Stacks, Double Linked Lists) work and what ready-to-use implementations programming languages offer. Furthermore we take an introductory look at algebra, set theory and predicate logic.

Learn-n-Tell

Inspired by Berlin's wonderful Hack-n-Tell (http://www.meetup.com/berlin-hack-and-tell), this is a chance for you to share with others what you have learned, what code you have written, some questions you have (there are no stupid questions!) or something you are stuck on. You don't have to prepare - all you need is 5 minutes. Bring your laptop - who knows - maybe there is something you have learned that is really helpful to others.

We suggest you grab something to eat before hand (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards.

description:
BioPython for beginners: reverse transcribe RNA to DNA, count point mutations, translate RNA to protein.

Are you a biologist who would like to perform these or more complicated tasks?

On November 12th at 19:30, you can learn how to handle biological sequences with Python.

In the first OTS workshop on biological data, you can make your first steps with the BioPython library. We are going to work on the Rosalind challenges, and hope to encourage you to improve your programming skills.

The workshop is suitable for all biologists with little programming experience. Our team of coaches is ready to assist you. Bring your own laptop and start learning!

description:
This is our fifth meetup, aimed at beginners learning to code and develop software. The format of the meetup will be:

Scheduled talks (20 mins each)

# The social side of programming – Giorgia Sambrotta

Even developers love social networks - can you believe it? And it can also be funny. We'll see how to share code, discuss it and collaborate on thousands of different projects through Github, the social coding website. We will cover how Github can make it possible and the principal points it uses to make programming a social environment.

Giorgia is a web designer working with Html/5, css/3, Sass and UX.
She's really interested in programming and development and her goal at the moment is to learn how to program with JavaScript, as she finds it's a very important skill for the future work of a web designer.
Giorgia is also a core member of OTS and sees it as a great chance to get in contact with a lot of interesting people and projects.

# An introduction to Arduino: the 5 Ws + 1 – Alessandro Contini

We will try to answer to the following questions: What is it? Who did that? When? Where? Why is it like that? …and, what can I do with it?

In a time when everyone is talking about makers, digital fabrication, 3D printing, laser cutting, DIY and so on, let's go back and see where everything began. Ok, not EVERYTHING actually, but let's say where everything took a big step forward. We'll also have a hands-on demo that you can't miss, so – less talk, more rock!

Alessandro is a tech savvy designer. He works with sounds, images and coding. After graduating in Computer Science and Music Technology in Milan he started collaborations with international companies such as Interaction Design Lab, Nokia, Eyebeam Art + Technology Center for the Arts, and taught classes at the Polytechnic Institute of Milan, NABA and Domus Academy. He's currently a Berlin based freelance creative technologist, interactive artist and regular hackathon-goer!

Learn-n-Tell

Inspired by Berlin's wonderful Hack-n-Tell (http://www.meetup.com/berlin-hack-and-tell), this is a chance for you to share with others what you have learned, what code you have written, some questions you have (there are no stupid questions!) or something you are stuck on. You don't have to prepare - all you need is 5 minutes. Bring your laptop - who knows - maybe there is something you have learned that is really helpful to others.

 

We suggest you grab something to eat before hand (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards.
name: Beginners Meetup #5

description:
Hello Everyone,

we are planning a cross between a meetup and a workshop: a "Meetshop" if you will!

The Topic: Math for Visuals!

We will start off a bit oldschool, using paper and scissors to create various geometric shapes! Then there will be a few presentations. StudioNAND http://www.nand.io will be on hand to speak on math/shapes in generative design using Processing. We will also have two other talks touching on topics of vectors, polar coordinates , linear transformation in 2D as well as a talk about the screen as a cartesian plane (coordinate system) covering basic 2D maths for visual programming. Finally, we'd like to have people creating their own geometric shapes and designs in the computer, so please bring your laptop with!

This meetshop is aimed at beginners and designers who are interested in learning more about math as it relates to visual design.
If you have anyway questions, please get in touch.
We hope to see you all there!
name: Math for Visuals: a "Meetshop"

description:
This is our meetup aimed at beginners learning to code and develop software.

Scheduled talk (~20 min)

# What are types good for? -- Emily Green

What are types and why do we use them? What do people mean when they say X
language is dynamic, or when they criticize/applaud language Y for being statically typed? Why do people care?

While we're at it, what on earth is duck typing and monkey patching? What
exactly is a "scripting language", how is it different to any other sort of
language?

Find out the answers to these questions are more!

Emily is a developer who went from Java to Scala to Haskell. She used to work in finance, and about 2 years ago moved to focus more on web apps and start-ups. She likes making stuff for real people!

Learn-n-Tell

Inspired by Berlin's wonderful Hack-n-Tell (http://www.meetup.com/berlin-hack-and-tell), this is a chance for you to share with others what you have learned, what code you have written, some questions you have (there are no stupid questions!) or something you are stuck on. You don't have to prepare - all you need is 5 minutes. Bring your laptop - who knows - maybe there is something you have learned that is really helpful to others.

Send us your ideas to team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

We suggest you grab something to eat before hand (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards. Look forward to seeing you!

Installation? Yes! So please don't forget to bring your computer and a smile.

See you there!

name: Android for Beginners - Install Party

description:
First released in November 2007, the mobile operating system Android grew from a niche competitor to the dominating system used by a variety of device manufacturers and Google’s most important products.

As smartphone use rises, people are getting more more interested in apps and how they are created. Our one-day workshop for beginners aims to enable learners to create their very first Android app.

 

What do we expect from learners?

Interest and an open mind. Prepare the machine (see prerequisites) and show up or free the seat. Basic programming knowledge. We'll be dealing with basic Java and XML. Not knowing a programming language at all could hold you up too long and can result in frustration - we want to avoid that.  

What can you expect from the workshop?

You understand how Android apps are built, can program your first app and carry it home on your phone (or start on the emulator). As always with OpenTechSchool this is a hands-on workshop, not a lecture. You'll be working in very small groups and a coach will always be on your side if you need it.

 

Prerequisites

Your own laptop running MacOS X (intel), Windows (x86/x64) or Linux (x86) with WIFI support Your own Android device is not needed but recommended. If you don't own one you can work with the emulator almost just as good. If you'll attend the install party, we will help you to set up your machine with the necessary tools. If you won't attend, you have to make sure you've installed:

A downloaded version of the Android SDK for your system (download here) Eclipse with Android Developer Tools (download here) If you are using your own phone you have to make sure you can access the device through adb which often requires specific USB drivers.  

Catering

Our gracious host co.up offers to buy drinks for 1,50 Euro each from the fridge against cash payment. As for food we can decide to go out for lunch or order in. You can also bring your own food, if you like.

More seats? Yes, but...!

We'd looove to offer more seats but the number of beginners is directly connected to the number of coaches we can find. If you know Android please think about joining our coaches mailing list (below the call for coaches here) and we'll add more seats to the workshop.

Questions? No problem, we'll be glad to answer them. Just comment below!

If you are confirmed (i.e. not on the waiting list) and you know you can't come please (!) free your seat for another learner. Thank you!
how_to_find_us: We'll be in the 3rd floor
name: Android for Beginners - Workshop Day

description:
Come together to hack together on your own stuff.

Every Saturday afternoon a few of us from the OpenTechSchool get together at Mein Haus am See to code and hack on our own projects. And we'd like everyone to tag along. Whether you are working on your secret startup mobile app or just going through an online course to learn coding, feel free to come by and hang with us. And in case you are stuck or have a question, there are other coders around to talk stuff through with.

Let the fun begin.

PS: This is no workshop and it's not guaranteed we'll stay there all day but we'd be happy to meet you.
how_to_find_us: Look for some friendly people with laptops.
name: Micro Hack Day

description:
Join us for a whole day of coding, interaction and fun! Following our first Processing session back in January, we are back with exciting news for all you creative coders! We are really happy to invite you to our first Processing Code Jam that will be kindly hosted by Betahaus next Saturday as part of Maker Weekend #2 (http://betahaus.de/event/maker-weekend-2/).

The focus of this Jam will be interaction and visuals so bring any material that you might need (midi-controllers, gamepads, Arduino, MaKey MaKey, iPad with touchOSC, sensors, camera, playdough, etc.)

Some previous experience with Processing (or Java) is recommended but everyone is welcome! Really! Designers, artists, coders, writers, game-designers, taxi-drivers, everyone! Don't worry if you never came to an OTS event before, we'll make presentations and the teams will form around a project and by affinity.

But wait, there's more! The results of the Jam will have the chance to be presented to a larger audience at the OPEN END PARTY that will be held in the evening. No pressure though, you will show your work only if you want to, but we think it'll make a perfect finale to this unique event!

Join and bring your friends!

Please post a theme suggestion for the Jam in the comments. We will hold a voting session to chose the main themes at the beginning of the day.
name: OTS Processing Sessions #2: Processing Code Jam

description:
After the really great first Introduction to programming in python back in September and many Mini-Python workshops on specific topics, we decided to rerun the starter workshop to enable more people without coding skills yet, to join the fun. So if you are interested to getting introduced to programming with the great PythonTurtle workshop we've prepared for you, please sign up.

You will need to bring your own laptop in order to participate with a recent python (2.7) installed. If you have a recent Mac or Linux, it is pre-installed, you are covered. If you are running Windows, please let the organizers know in advance, so they can help you set it up.

The space is wheelchair accessible; please call the mobile number posted at the door so we can send down the elevator for you. If you have any special needs, please don't hesitate to let us know.

Because the number of seats is limited, it is important that you only sign up if you definitely plan on coming (and do so, too!). If you can't make it for any reason, please cancel your attendance on Meetup right away so your someone on the waiting list can take your place. Thanks!
name: Workshop: Introduction to programming with python

description:
Join us once again as we meet to discuss the finer points of design as it relates to UI/UX!

We have a couple of talks scheduled. Tiffany Conroy will present on The Limits of Context: When to use Ajax and when to reload. Astrid Bin joins us as well to discuss designing a UI under time constraints and her general approach to design. Hany Rizk will also be there to give a presentation about cognitive psychology in UX and design! Promises to be an interesting meetup! See you all there!

description:
The OpenTechSchool Learners Meetup (formerly Beginners Meetup) is aimed at everyone who wants to learn to code and develop software.

Each event has:

* a main talk (from an experienced coder addressing beginners or from a beginner willing to give a talk)

* presentations of tech hands-on events suitable for beginners

* Learn'n'Tell session, open to all beginners who want to ask tech-related questions or present their hacks and projects.

Both absolute beginners and more experienced coders who want to share their knowledge and learn something new are welcome!

Beginners! Propose your talk  or presentation and come to give it at our next events! We're glad to help you with feedback on the presentation before hand if you want. Get in contact with us: team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org!

//////////////////////////////////////////

This month we'll focus on HACKS! How to use an API (Why all these hackathons talk about APIs?) and a hackathon who welcomes beginners (happening in a few days!)

 

Talk (~20 min)

# What are APIs and how do we use them? – Duana Stanley @starkcoffee

Duana will give a very high level overview of APIs, how you can use them, what the difference is between an API and an SDK, what are "endpoints", what is REST and what is OAUTH (!)

Duana is a Software Engineer at SoundCloud currently doing a lot of backend Rails development. She is one of the organizers of this meetup!

Presentation (~10 min)

# Berlin Mini Game Jam. Featured event – Iwan Gabovitch @qubodup

The Berlin Mini Game Jam is a relaxed monthly hackathon with a workshop approach. Attendees choose a theme together, form teams or go solo to make game concepts and prototypes on computers, phones, cardboard or physical space. Anyone from beginners to experienced coders and game designers is welcome. In this talk, Iwan will give a short walkthrough through a jam session and present some results from past jams. Next jam: Saturday, 8th March at co.up! http://www.berlinminijam.de/

Iwan has been an avid computer game player for most of his life and attending a game jam was the turning point for his involvement in the actual creation of games.He has been co-organizing the Berlin Mini Game Jam  since late 2010 in a team of three. He since worked on the independently developed game "Nikki and the Robots" and now creates sound effects for video games and other media. http://qubodup.net

Learn-n-Tell

Inspired by Berlin's wonderful Hack-n-Tell (http://www.meetup.com/berlin-hack-and-tell), this is a chance for you to share with others what you have learned, what code you have written, some questions you have (there are no stupid questions!) or something you are stuck on.

You don't have to prepare - all you need is 5 minutes. Bring your laptop - who knows - maybe there is something you have learned that is really helpful to others.

Do you already have in mind something to ask or present at the Learn'n'Tell session? If you write us before the Meetup, we'll be glad to reserve a spot for you in the Learn'n'Tell line-up. Get in contact with us: team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org!

 

We suggest you grab something to eat before the event (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go on until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards. We are looking forward to seeing you!
name: Learners Meetup

description:
Come together to hack together on your own stuff.

Every Saturday afternoon can be your dedicated project time. Be it your work from the week, the pet project, your new start-up or "just" the next lessons on codeacademy - sit down and get cracking. Why not do that at home? Because this will be a hangout for all kinds of people and so you can chat in your breaks, get to know new people and help each other out when you're stuck.

Although it's announced on our meetup group a few things to note about this meetup:

It's not guaranteed you'll have a OTS member/coach present. There won't be any prepared talks or workshops. There are other people and music, too. Also the WIFI is flaky sometimes. We are offering this as an easier way to meet other learners. Please ping us if you have suggestions to make this event more useful to you all.

description:
hey everyone, come out this Tuesday, we'll be talking fonts (Dan Reynolds) and adaptive design (Diego Margini)!

Kick-start your type prowess
Dan Reynolds

Typography is intertwined with almost any information hierarchy found in visual design today. Indeed, from the written word to the printed word to words on screen, the navigability of a text has always been a key consideration in a document’s success. This meet-up presentation will detail a few aspects about how to approach typography in your projects. The points discussed will be offered with the reader or user in mind, and should be a helpful explanation for designers at any level.

Diego Margini's talk:

While creating flexible layouts is important, there's a whole lot more that goes into truly exceptional adaptive web experiences. This session will introduce the Principles of Adaptive Design: ubiquity, flexibility, performance, enhancement and future-friendliness. We need go beyond media queries in order to preserve the web's ubiquity and move it in a future-friendly direction.

You will also need to bring your own laptop with a recent version of Python (2.6 or 2.7) installed. If you have a recent Mac or Linux, it is pre-installed, so you are covered. The workshop is free of charge. You are invited to bring some food to share. Drinks and brezel are offert by our amazing sponsor, ImmobilienScout24.

Also, if the list is already full, sign up for the waiting list. Depending on the amount of coaches, we might gonna raise the participants we can take later...

description:
Join us for a day of coding, interaction and fun! Following the success our first Processing Code Jam back in February, we are back with a new edition! It will be bigger, better, stronger!

The Processing Code Jam is an open creative coding workshop inspired by the Berlin Mini Game Jam. We choose a theme for the day and make teams or go solo to build a generative, interactive or otherwise code-based creations.

Bring your ideas, hardware, friends and some food to keep you going during this whole day of relaxed (but intense) computational creativity. The jam will be followed by a presentation of the projects.

Some previous experience with Processing is recommended but everyone is welcome! Really! Designers, artists, coders, writers, game-designers, musicians, everyone! And don't be put off by the “Processing” label; users of PureData, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, Touch Designer, and the others are also very welcome! Don't worry if you never came to an OTS event before, we'll make presentations and the teams will form around a project and by affinity.

The event is free thanks to co.up coworking. You can return their kindness by buying some of their 1.50€ drinks!

There's only one rule: “If this is your first time at the Processing Code Jam, you have to code!”

 

Note: Please post a theme suggestion for the Jam in the comments. We will hold a voting session to chose the main themes at the beginning of the day.
name: Processing Code Jam

description:
We have a new meetup with a new format!

The idea of the Learners Meetup is to have a monthly slot where we can rock up and

hear talks which are on a level we can understand connect with other people learning tech to share knowledge, help and motivate each other Learners of all levels are welcome, especially absolute beginners. As a beginner you get access to people who may be able to help you, and as a more experienced programmer you can share your expertise and train your mentoring skills by being a coach.

The new format we will try:

Welcome and introduction to coaches - what can you help someone with? 15 minute scheduled talk - the talks are aimed so that everyone can get something out of it, no matter what their level of experience or programming language. A “mini barcamp” - anyone can propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into discussion groups or pairs. At the end we get together as a group and summarised what we discussed. The scheduled talk will be:

Testing, testing 123... with Benjamin Kampmann How do developers test their code? What is a unit test? What other kinds of tests are there? What is test driven development? We'll give you an introduction!

We suggest you grab something to eat before the event (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go on until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards. We are looking forward to seeing you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at  team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
Everyone is talking about makers, digital fabrication, 3D printing, laser cutting, DIY and you’ve heard about these incredible projects they are doing with Arduino, right?

 

Ok, but what is it exactly? And what can you do with it?

 

Come to the first OTS "Arduino for beginners" workshop and you will find out while actually building circuits and writing code to make LEDs blink and buzzers sing!

 

You'll be guided step by step from the installation of the software to building and programming a real electronic musical instrument, plus it's for beginners so previous experience with coding and electronics is not required.

 

If you've never heard about Arduino before it's an open source platform designed "for artists, designers, hobbyists, and anyone interested in creating interactive objects or environments." (www.arduino.cc)

On top of that it's also an intuitive and fun way to learn programming!

 

Details:

You will need a laptop and an Arduino Starter Kit (with Arduino UNO board) which you can find online here:

http://de.rs-online.com/web/p/entwicklungskits-prozessor-microcontroller/7617355/?

or in Berlin here:

http://shop.fritzing.org/

http://www.segor.de

http://www.tinkersoup.de/index.php?cPath=55


If you already own an Arduino kit please be sure you bring the components you can find in this list:

http://bit.ly/18PvSvz

 

If you own an Arduino Lilypad or are planning to buy one to work on wearable technology, please check this list instead: http://www.kobakant.at/DIY/?p=4268

 

In case you already own a different Arduino board, or you have interest in buying a different version of Arduino, please write to alessandro@opentechschool.org before registering so we can try and find a solution for you!

 

Because the number of seats is limited, it is important that you only sign up if you definitely plan on coming (and do so, too!). If you can't make it for any reason, please cancel your attendance on Meetup right away so your someone on the waiting list can take your place.

Thanks!

 

Registration for this workshop will open on Tuesday 21st May at 11a.m.
name: Arduino for beginners workshop

description:
Last month we tried out our new format that works pretty well, so here we are again for another event where we can learn about programming together.

New Format:

Welcome and introduction to coaches - what can you help someone with? 15 minute scheduled talk - the talks are aimed so that everyone can get something out of it, no matter what their level of experience or programming language. A “mini barcamp” - anyone can propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into discussion groups or pairs. At the end we get together as a group and summarised what we discussed. Scheduled Talk:

Text processing by Martin Stadler

Because is all about text data! How you can manipulate and filter that data? Martin will show us, also through live coding examples, what is encoding (and that "utf-8"?), search and replace strings, regular expressions (how to find and replace text patterns) and even more.

Also:

Stephan from the Django User Group will give us a short presentation about their next meeting and why is great for beginners to join it.

------------------------------------------------------------------

The idea of the Learners Meetup is to have a monthly slot where we can rock up and

hear talks which are on a level we can understand connect with other people learning tech to share knowledge, help and motivate each other Learners of all levels are welcome, especially absolute beginners. As a beginner you get access to people who may be able to help you, and as a more experienced programmer you can share your expertise and train your mentoring skills by being a coach.

------------------------------------------------------------------

We suggest you grab something to eat before the event (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go on until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards. We are looking forward to seeing you!

Ideas/questions?

Email us at  team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
Summer in Berlin has a pretty low signal-to-noise ratio, don't you think? What better way to cope with a flimsy sunlight than a friendly gathering with fellow creative coders?

The Processing Code Jam is an open creative coding event based on a simple idea: build a project from scratch in a day. It is a place to experiment, meet other coders, get creative, challenge yourself (and maybe even fail spectacularly!) It's all okay and there will be no pressure other than self-imposed: build it, show it, throw it!

The way it works is we choose a theme for the day and make teams or go solo to build a generative, interactive or otherwise code-based prototypes. Some previous experience with Processing is recommended but everyone can join! Designers, artists, coders, writers, game-designers, musicians, everyone! And don't be put off by the “Processing” label; users of PureData, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, Touch Designer, and others are also very welcome.

Bring your ideas, hardware, friends and some food to keep you going during this whole day of relaxed (but intense) computational creativity. The jam will be followed by a presentation of the projects. Don't worry if you never came to an OTS event before, we'll make presentations and the teams will form around a project and by affinity.

There's only one rule: “If this is your first time at the Processing Code Jam, you have to code!”

The event is free thanks to co.up coworking. You can return their kindness by buying some of their 1.50€ drinks!

Note: Please post a theme suggestion for the Jam in the comments. We will hold a voting session to chose the main themes at the beginning of the day. In case you wonder what a theme looks like, here are the ones from the previous edition: "the color of sound", "grasshoppers" and "time".

description:
It's never been easier to make video games, thanks to the multitude of resources available and a growing worldwide community willing to help beginners. As a result, new games are being released every day, exploring different directions and tackling novel themes: playing is more stimulating and inclusive than ever.

Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level. If you like video games, we'll make sure you have a good time!

The event is split into two parts:

1. TALK: a couple of short game-related talks, followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge

2. PLAY: games made by the speakers will be shown; in addition, all participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and maybe find collaborators too

The speakers at Talk & Play #1 will be:

Tinytouchtales is a Berlin-based duo, which strives to create games and interactive stories for touch screen devices. In August 2012 Wiebke Rauers and Arnold Floeck teamed up with the desire to create their own projects apart from working in the film/animation and casual games business. So far they have released three iOS games and several prototypes for game jams such as Ludum Dare or the Global Game Jam. Their latest project is an interactive kids' book, which integrates games into a self written and fully illustrated story. Tinytouchtales is planning to go full-time indie at the beginning of 2014. They will talk about making games without a programmer.

S. Astrid Bin is an artist and designer. She makes installations, performances, games, experiences, objects, sounds and images. She will present her game Panic!, an interactive story made with Twine, a free and open source software, possibly the simplest game making tool available today.

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #1

description:
New Format:

A “mini barcamp” - anyone can propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into discussion groups or pairs. At the end we get together as a group and summarised what we discussed. Scheduled Talk:

Learning techniques rather than technologies by Ellen Koenig

In our software development jobs, we frequently find ourselves applying and polishing existing skills rather than expanding into new ones. Yet with technology always changing and developers being eternally curious, we need effective learning skills to master new subjects effectively. Psychologist have identified the principles of what it takes to master new skills: Challenge, clear goals, feedback, repetition, concentration. In this talk Ellen will show how these principles can be applied to learning different programming languages, frameworks and technologies as well as software development methods using examples for learning goals, feedback mechanism and repetition strategies.

------------------------------------------------------------------

The idea of the Learners Meetup is to have a monthly slot where we can rock up and

hear talks which are on a level we can understand connect with other people learning tech to share knowledge, help and motivate each other Learners of all levels are welcome, especially absolute beginners. ------------------------------------------------------------------

Mini barcamp doesn't include any private room for group discussion nor projector. Is more about friendly discussion about what you are curious about with the tool we have right there. :)

description:
Join us to make stories into interactive games using Twine, a free and open source interactive fiction tool. The event is designed as a mini game jam: the goal is for everyone to have a finished game available online by the end of the day.

WHAT IS TWINE?

Twine is a free tool for creating interactive fiction. It's gained notoriety because it enables people who are not programmers to make text games. It's simple to use and requires no programming skills – though if you're really interested it can be expanded using a little programming, but this isn't necessary.

WHO IS THIS FOR?

This event is for anyone who has an interest in games and stories. We're especially welcoming to people who are first-time game makers, as well as artists, designers and writers who may not have thought about making a game before. We also welcome experienced game designers and programmers. Twine is a simple-to-use tool, but developers can feel free to expand or extend it by using available modules, or writing their own (GitHub repo).

WHY SHOULD I COME?

A game jam is a great way to spend an afternoon with friendly people making and finishing something! You'll go through the whole process from concept to completion. You can work alone or in small groups, and you don't need any programming skills at all. We present themes at the beginning of the day that you can use to create a story, as well as some short talks that will tell you everything you need to know about using Twine and participating in a game jam. We'll also have people on hand to help with creative and technical questions.

HOW'S THE EVENT STRUCTURED?

1100: Doors
1200: Short talks telling you everything you need to know about using Twine and getting things done on time
1230: START JAMMING!
1730: Upload your finished product
1800: Presentations (open to everyone)

WANT TO KNOW MORE ABOUT TWINE?

Some Twine games you should try: Panic!, Howling Dogs, Brooklyn Trash King, Reset, Memorial

A list of Twine resources

An interesting article about the "Twine revolution"

- - - - -

This event is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam

description:
New Format:

• Welcome and introduction to coaches - what can you help someone with? 

• 15 minute scheduled talk - the talks are aimed so that everyone can get something out of it, no matter what their level of experience or programming language. 

• A “mini barcamp” - anyone can propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into discussion groups or pairs. At the end we get together as a group and summarised what we discussed.

Scheduled Talk:

The magic of text encoding: How to safely handle ßêñśÞ and other funky characters - Dave Brotherstone

Computers store everything as numbers - long rows of zeros and ones to be exact. So how do we get computers to store all the wonderful and funky characters of the various alphabets in this world? If you ever came across a non-English webpage or text document where all the "special" characters have been replaced by odd stuff like question marks or empty squares, you have experienced the practical difficulties in storing text as numerical representations. Dave will explain to us in a very simple way why that happens and how to avoid falling into this and other traps while working with text as a programmer.

------------------------------------------------------------------

The idea of the Learners Meetup is to have a monthly slot where we can rock up and hear talks which are on a level we can understand,
connect with other people learning tech to share knowledge, help and motivate each other.

Learners of all levels are welcome, especially absolute beginners. As a beginner you get access to people who may be able to help you, and as a more experienced programmer you can share your expertise and train your mentoring skills by being a coach.

------------------------------------------------------------------

We suggest you grab something to eat before the event (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go on until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards. We are looking forward to seeing you!

The mini barcamp doesn't include any private room for group discussion nor projector. It is more about friendly discussion about what you are curious about with the tool we have right there. :)

Ideas/questions?

Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
Hi everyone!

As you may have noticed, the Processing Code Jam kinda missed a beat. How have you been? We hope you enjoyed the sun.

Processing Code Jam is usually an 8 hour collaborative creative coding event. However, this session will be a little different. We are organizing a more relaxed Friday evening jam and open discussion time. The usual whole day jams will resume in September.

Since it's in the evening and in a condensed form, let's make it a Show & Tell stammtisch! Bring something to eat and a project you want to present. It can be some prototype you've been working on, some interesting contributed library you found or even someone else's work you think is interesting. You can also submit an issue to the crowd we'll try to help you solve it. Of course, there will still be the option to seat and prototype a sketch for the duration of the event. Choose your adventure!

Note: Co.up coworking is kindly hosting our event for free. You can return the favor by purchasing their fresh drinks for €1.50.

description:
Ever wanted to learn how websites work or wanted to build one yourself? Or maybe you have played around with some HTML but wonder how to get it to actually do something? Now is the time to start with our Websites with Python Flask workshop. We’ll take you through creating a basic interactive website using Flask, a very popular choice for websites created using the Python programming language.

To make the most out of this workshop, you should already have a very basic understanding of Python, such as from our Introduction to programming with Python tutorial. If haven't done this yet, you can also come and work through that workshop instead.

The learning materials are quite substantial for an evening session, so you might not finish all the exercises. But this is not a problem at all because you can go on at our new Continuous Python Learning Group where coaches will be around to help.

You will only need to bring your own laptop with a recent version of Python (2.6, 2.7 or 3.3+) installed. If you have a recent Mac or Linux, it is pre-installed, so you are covered. If you are running Windows and need help setting up Python, please let the organizers know in advance.

RSVP opens three weeks in advance on Tuesday, August 6th, 2013 at 6:30pm. Because the number of seats is limited, it is important that you only sign up if you definitely plan on coming (and do so, too!). If you can't make it for any reason, please cancel your attendance on Meetup right away so someone on the waiting list can take your place. Thanks!
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Workshop: Websites with Python Flask

description:
It's never been easier to make video games, thanks to the multitude of resources available and a growing worldwide community willing to help beginners. As a result, new games are being released every day, exploring different directions and tackling novel themes: playing is more stimulating and inclusive than ever.

Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level. If you like video games, we'll make sure you have a good time!

The event is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks, followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge.

2. PLAY: games made or chosen by the speakers will be shown; in addition, all participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and maybe find collaborators.

To give you a better idea, here's a recap of the first Talk & Play.

The speakers at Talk & Play #1 will be:

• Cay Kellinghusen, founder and project manager of Game Science Center, an independent creative exhibition space slated to open in the next few months in Berlin. He will tell us more about the project, which looks very promising.

• Christian Stanke started working in the games industry about three years ago. He recently founded his first own company "embraase" together with a long time colleague to build developer tools that put the power to operate a game the way top tier studios do it into the hands of every aspiring game developer. He will share some tips on how to get game press coverage.

• U55 – End of the line is a "survival horror adventure set in the subway system of modern-day Berlin" inspired by H. P. Lovecraft: sounds a bit crazy, but it looks great – Alexander Kuprijanow will do his best to convince you to support the game on Kickstarter.

• The organisers of the Science Hack Day Berlin will give a short presentation of the upcoming event. It's the kind of thing some "game people" might find interesting...

During the second part of the evening we're going to have an Oculus Rift, possibly showing some of the games made during the VR Jam in Berlin – a great opportunity to try this device everyone's talking about.

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #2

description:
Format:

• Welcome and introduction to coaches - what can you help someone with?

• 15 minute scheduled talk - the talks are aimed so that everyone can get something out of it, no matter what their level of experience or programming language.

• A “mini barcamp” - anyone can propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into discussion groups or pairs. At the end we get together as a group and summarised what we discussed.

Scheduled Talk: Playing with the "MVC" concept (Ellen König)
The keyword "MVC" is tossed around all the time in different contexts when talking about web applications. Even if you know that the letters stand for "Model-View-Controller", that still is not very illuminating. Model, view and controller are builing blocks (or components) for a solution to the problem of keeping data (such as user inputs or products in a shop) and application state (such as: which users are logged in?) in sync between the user interface (e.g. the web page you see in a browser) and the backend (e.g. a database). So how do these three builing blocks work together to achieve this?`In this OTS learners meetup, we will explore this question together via a short and fun role-playing game. Join us and see from the inside what it "feels" like to be a model, view, controller or other essential part of a web framework!

------------------------------------------------------------------

description:
Hello processors. Did we really skip two months? Some of us tackled new projects, some travelled, some made new friends, some enjoyed the sun... Now it's September already and your favorite creative coding gathering is back! What have you been up to this summer?

The Processing Code Jam is an open, collaborative, creative coding event based on a simple idea: build a project from scratch in a day. It is a place to experiment with procedurally generated art, meet other creators, and get inspired.

We will start by voting for a theme for the day, do a bit of brainstorming then each of us will gather in teams or go solo to build a generative, interactive or otherwise code-based prototypes. At the end of the day, everyone gets the opportunity to show what they came up with during a short presentation.

Bring your ideas, hardware, friends and some food to keep you going during this whole day of relaxed (but intense) computational creativity. The jam will be followed by a presentation of the projects. Don't worry if you never came to an OTS event before, we'll make presentations and the teams will form around a project and by affinity.

Collaboration is great. The more cross-disciplinary, the better. Designers, musicians, artists, writers, game-designers, everyone can join! Don't be put off by the “Processing” label either, users of PureData, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, Touch Designer, and others are also very welcome.

Note to programmers: This is not a Processing workshop or a creative coding course. You will enjoy it more if you already have some basics skills in Processing or creative coding in general. However, beginners are very welcome and working in a team with more experienced coders can also be a great way to learn.

The event is free thanks to co.up coworking. You can return their kindness by buying some of their 1.50€ drinks!

Note: Please post a theme suggestion for the Jam in the comments. We will hold a voting session to chose the main themes at the beginning of the day.
name: Processing Code Jam

description:
Curious about the process of building an iPhone app? Join us for this free, two-hour workshop which will cover the iPhone application development process, best practices and tools of the trade.

Participants will be introduced to the development tools focusing on the XCode environment and will learn how to build a simple iPhone application. In addition, we'll integrate the Facebook SDK to show you how to log in with Facebook and make basic queries on user data.

Prerequisites

• Mac Computer

• Download XCode (Version 4.63)

Instructor: Eliot Arntz

Eliot is a full time developer with iOS development agency, BitFountain. He has worked on a variety of iOS projects including building games, photo applications and client work. Outside of his work with BitFountain he regularly teaches workshops on iOS development and coaches students in a one-on-one environment. Eliot is also the Lead Organizer of the iOS Office Hours Meetup in NYC and Founder of <a>Code Coalition</a>.

For more info about the event, feel free to check out Berlin iOS User Group. Hope to see you all there:)
name: iOS for Beginners

description:
The workshop Day. A Saturday full of free and open workshop ready for you. An event in collaboration with OTS, RailsGirls & PyLadies

Come to our evening party: http://www.meetup.com/opentechschool-berlin/events/145721252/

In Berlin you can learn Python, Ruby, Javascript or Php but even if you are a pro on these languages is complicated to develop a good product without the most worldwide, common and important Markup language: Html.

And since looks also count, Css are here for adjust the style.

So if you're interested to getting introduced to Html and Css world, come to the workshop we've prepared for you, please sign up.

You'll need to bring your own laptop in order to participate.
You don't need to install anything particular. You will need just your favourite text editor and a browser.
If you have any problem with it or you don't know which browser/text editor choose, don't worry we can do it together at the workshop.
Instead, if you don't have anything installed yet but you would prefer to arrive at the workshop already prepared our coaches suggested for you to install:
Text Editor: Sublime 2
Browser: Google Chrome

You are invited to bring your food and drinks in the pic-nick style. Everybody brings something and share with others and let's have a lunch all together!! (Of' course you are free to go out for a lunch but please notice that around there, there aren't so many place where to eat)

Because the number of seats is limited, it is important that you only sign up if you definitely plan on coming (and do so, too!). If you can't make it for any reason, please cancel your attendance on Meetup right away so your someone on the waiting list can take your place. Thanks.

We look forward to seeing you there!
how_to_find_us: The workhsop will be in the ScoutCasino. Get inside of ImmoblienScout and find the Cafeteria
name: The workshop Day:  Html/css for beginners

description:
On Saturday, October 19, OpenTechSchool, RailsGirls and PyLadies will run parallel workshops in town – it's a Workshop Day in Berlin!

And after a day spent learning new awesome code, it's time to take a break and share your excitement about what you just learned with all the others workshop heroes! :)

That's why we - OpenTechSchool , RailsGirls & PyLadies - want to celebrate with you, all together with a dinner/evening party right after the workshops.

Join us for a pic-nic style dinner (everybody invited to bring some food to share with the community) or feel free also to stop just for a drink, to meet learners from the other workshops, discover how was their learning experience, which magic programming languages they learned – and get inspired to try out new languages and workshops in the future!

And don't forget to have a fun – in the end it's still Saturday night in Berlin!

We're looking forward to celebrating this amazing Workshop Day with you all! (More details coming soon)
name: The Workshop Day Party - OpenTechSchool, RailsGirls & PyLadies

description:
It's never been easier to make video games, thanks to the multitude of resources available and a growing worldwide community willing to help beginners. As a result, new games are being released every day, exploring different directions and tackling novel themes: playing is more stimulating and inclusive than ever.

Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level. If you like video games, we'll make sure you have a good time!

The event is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks (5 to 15 minutes), followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge.

2. PLAY: games made or chosen by the speakers will be shown; in addition, all participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and maybe find collaborators.

To give you a better idea of what you're going to find, check out this summary of the first and second Talk & Play.

The three speakers this time have got something in common: they're all new Berliners! So let's get to know and give a warm welcome to:

– Black Pants Studio (from Kassel, Germany), authors of the award-winning game Tiny & Big and of About Love, Hate and the Other Ones

– Fernando Ramallo (from Argentina), the man behind Panoramical, Snaaake!, #lostlevels and Fuck This Jam!, among other things

– Stephen Lavelle aka Increpare (from UK), who made English Country Tune + almost 200 other games (maybe more?) and very recently released a brilliant open source HTML5 puzzle game engine called PuzzleScript 

Would you like to give a talk as well in the future? Get in touch!

During the second part of the evening we're going to have an Oculus Rift and an OUYA for you to try, in addition to the usual selection of fantastic games made by local developers.

Subscribe to our newsletter</a> for sporadic updates about the event and other game-related activities in Berlin.

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly <a href="http://www.meetup.com/game-developers-berlin/">Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #3

description:
The Creative Code Jam (formerly Processing Code Jam) is a monthly collaborative computational art event. It is free and open to all, regardless of age, gender, or previous experience. 

Please read the following description before you join! You will enjoy it more.

What is this event?
A relaxed (but intense) prototyping day. Participants are encouraged to form teams, improvise and create something together in a limited time. Asking questions throughout the day is encouraged!

Who is this event for?
 Artists (New Media or otherwise), technologists, designers, makers, and code enthusiasts of all kinds. If you are creative and like a bit of challenge, this one is for you. 

What this event is not. 
The Creative Code Jam is not a lesson, a contest or a conference.

What is Creative Coding?
Creative coding is the art of expressing oneself through the medium of computation.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer or other computational weapon of choice. Interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials and snacks to share are also always a good idea :)

Theme suggestion
Please suggest a theme in the comments below. Themes can be random topics like "beagles", "survival of the fattest" or "killer clowns", creative constrains like "the source code should fit in a Tweet" (wink wink Abe Pazos) or inspirational quotes. I love this one from "Famous New Media Artist" Jeremy Bailey: "I want to make things people eventually believe were inevitable but now seem utterly ridiculous."

Where is it?
Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

The place is a bit hard to find. This should help:
http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking
name: Creative Code Jam

name: Continuous Python Learning Group

description:
Format:

• Welcome and introduction to coaches. What can you help someone with? And if you're looking for help: spot your coach!

• 15 minute scheduled talk - the talks are designed to enable everyone to get something out of it, no matter what their level of experience or programming language.

• A mini barcamp! - anyone can propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into discussion groups or pairs. At the end we get together as a group and summarise what we discussed.

------------------------------------------------------------------

This time the scheduled talk is:
Learn to Love the Command Line, by Andreas Hug

Why do programmers use the command line so much? What are its origins? How do you learn the commands and what are the main concepts to know? We'll explore the command line together – bring your questions!

Andreas is technical lead at Moccu, a digital agency based in Berlin. Most of the time he uses Python and Django to build backend systems for websites and web applications. He also likes to tweak the agency's workflow with various tools and techniques. At OpenTechSchool Andreas is mainly engaged in the Python group where he organizes workshops and contributes to the learning materials.
------------------------------------------------------------------

The idea of the Learners Meetup is to have a monthly slot where we can rock up and hear talks which are on a level we can understand, connect with other people learning tech to share knowledge, help and motivate each other.

Learners of all levels are welcome, especially absolute beginners. As a beginner you get access to people who may be able to help you, and as a more experienced programmer you can share your expertise and train your mentoring skills by being a coach.

------------------------------------------------------------------

We suggest you grab something to eat before the event (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go on until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards. We are looking forward to seeing you!

Ideas/questions?

Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
name: Learners Meetup

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We are in the 3rd or 5th floor, please check the signs
name: Continuous Python Learning Group

description:
It's never been easier to make video games, thanks to the multitude of resources available and a growing worldwide community willing to help beginners. As a result, new games are being released every day, exploring different directions and tackling novel themes: playing is more stimulating and inclusive than ever.

Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level. If you like video games, we'll make sure you have a good time!

The event is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks (5 to 15 minutes), followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge.

2. PLAY: games made or chosen by the speakers will be shown; in addition, all participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and maybe find collaborators.

To give you a better idea of what you're going to find, check out these summaries of the first, second and third Talk & Play.

The speakers at Talk & Play #4 will be:

Canupa, a Berlin based indie game studio, will talk about their latest release Omicron, a colour reaction game for one or two players on the same touch screen device. It's beautiful and you should try it!

Martin Reiche, an audiovisual installation and game artist living and working in Berlin, co-founder and head member of the Laboratory for the Analysis of Social Networks (LASN) at Karlsruhe University of Arts and Design and co-founder of the Subformat Research Group. He will talk about how the art market works and how game creators can benefit from that. 

Kristina Rothe, game development evangelist at Microsoft with a background in game development, publishing and journalism, has worked at Travian Games and Square Enix Europe in the past. The title of her talk is "Three things to help your game get noticed", which is quite self-explanatory!

The organisers of the Global Game Jam Berlin 2014 (save the date: January 24-26) will present some of the games made during previous GGJ in Berlin to show you that spending 48 sleepless hours with other people can be magical.

A MAZE. / Berlin 2014 (formerly Indie Connect) has just been announced, the tickets for the festival and the submissions for the awards are now open. Festival director Thorsten S. Wiedemann will give an anticipation of what to expect from the event and invite us to the upcoming Hyper Room party on December 7.

Would you like to give a talk as well in the future? Then get in touch!

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #4

description:
Format:

• Welcome and introduction to coaches. What can you help someone with? And if you're looking for help: spot your coach!

• 15 minute scheduled talk - the talks are designed to enable everyone to get something out of it, no matter what their level of experience or programming language.

• A mini barcamp! - anyone can propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into discussion groups or pairs. At the end we get together as a group and summarise what we discussed.

------------------------------------------------------------------

This time the scheduled talk is:
Pair Programming – What is it? Why do we do it? I'll give some tips of various configurations I've tried and some tips I've learnt over the years. This is an adapted presentation I gave to a class of high school students. There will be comics!

Duana is a senior software engineer working at SoundCloud. She is an organizer of the Learner's Meetup and loves OpenTechSchool and the ideas behind it.
------------------------------------------------------------------

The idea of the Learners Meetup is to have a monthly slot where we can rock up and hear talks which are on a level we can understand, connect with other people learning tech to share knowledge, help and motivate each other.

Learners of all levels are welcome, especially absolute beginners. As a beginner you get access to people who may be able to help you, and as a more experienced programmer you can share your expertise and train your mentoring skills by being a coach.

------------------------------------------------------------------

We suggest you grab something to eat before the event (or bring it with you) as the evening tends to go on until around 9pm. We usually also have some drinks afterwards. We are looking forward to seeing you!

Ideas/questions?

Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
name: Learners Meetup

description:
What is this event? 

Creative Coding Stammtisch (formerly known as Processing Stammtisch) is a friendly gathering of Creative Coders who like to work with programs such as Processing, openFrameworks, SuperCollider, Pure Data, vvvv, Arduino, Cinder, etc. 

The atmosphere is relaxed. There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions.

It is free and open to artists, designers, and code enthusiasts, regardless of age, gender or programming level. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome and free to ask questions.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stammtisch

What should I bring?
Bring your computer. Snacks are also a good idea :)

Where is it?
Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

The place is a bit hard to find. This should help:
http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking
name: Creative Coding Stammtisch

description:
Come together to hack together on your own stuff.

Every Saturday afternoon can be your dedicated project time. Be it your work from the week, the pet project, your new start-up or "just" the next lessons on codeacademy - sit down and get cracking. Why not do that at home? Because this will be a hangout for all kinds of people and so you can chat in your breaks, get to know new people and help each other out when you're stuck.

Although it's announced on our meetup group a few things to note about this meetup:

It's not guaranteed you'll have a OTS member/coach present. There won't be any prepared talks or workshops. There are other people and music, too. Also the WIFI is flaky sometimes. We are offering this as an easier way to meet other learners. Please ping us if you have suggestions to make this event more useful to you all.

The first one to come, put up a paper easily visible for everyone, stating that there is the OTS Learners hangout so that others can find you.
how_to_find_us: We'll meet in the café downstairs, Look for some friendly people with laptops.

description:
~ Arduino, Raspberry Pi, Interactive installations, Creative coding, Hardware hacking…
If that sounds familiar (or inviting) then it’s time for you to join the Physical Computing Club!

We will work in groups or on our own and will show and share what we’ll learn at the end of the meeting in an informal show&tell tea party.

Bring your ideas and all the tools you think you’ll need for your hack.
Feel free to use the comment section of this event to share your idea and discuss how to realize them.

Meeting 1.0
~ The theme for the first meeting will be “Surfing On Sine Waves (Arduino + Sound)”: how to generate and manipulate audio signals with a simple microcontroller, creating synthesizers, sequencers or interactive sound/music devices.

What is it?
~ The physical computing club is a monthly gathering open to all enthusiasts to tinker, hack and collaborate on hardware projects and share our experiences.

Every meeting will have a theme and will feature a “maker in house” to inspire us with a lighting talk on the theme of the day, and help us learning new hardware and coding tricks.

Some of the planned themes so far:
- surfing on sine waves (Arduino and Sound), going wireless (Wifi modules), e-textiles (Lilypad), PCB prototyping (Fritzing/Eagle), making sensors, serial communication, visualize it (Processing), ...

Note: this an advanced topic hack day, not a workshop, and as such not very suitable for beginners. (If you’re a complete beginner in physical computing don’t be scared, OTS will be giving an “Intro to Arduino Workshop” that will give you the chance to feel comfortable with the basics of electronics and creative coding! Look for a beginner workshop to take place early on in the new year!)

Details
If you can’t find the Fablab please call: 0176 20504057

Feel free to bring snacks!
name: Physical Computing Club — 1.0

description:
For years I've had a tradition of watching movies and eating popcorn on Jan. 1st, now let's do this OTS Community-style! To promote our Hackership/crowdfunding campaign (http://igg.me/at/hackership) to raise funds for our own OTS/Hackership space in 2014, we're organizing a day of community and movies and popcorn, oh my!

Make your movie suggestions* in the comments below! If you've made any short films this year, they can be shown as an opener, just let me know (rachel@opentechschool.org)! Drinks will be provided by co-up for €1.50 a piece. Bring your hang-overs and your craving for munchies (well, popcorn, really) and your Hackership donations (see above) and let's celebrate the new year together!

*some of my own suggestions, but i'm open to yours, of course!

War Games from the 80's (kinda about coding): 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbqMuvnx5MU

District 9 (about the future of aliens and tech--again, kinda):

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DyLUwOcR5pk

:)

venue.name: Fab Lab Berlin

description:
Important Note: To sign-up for this meetup-- you must use this Eventbrite link! If you signed up previously on this meetup page-- it does not secure you a spot!

Most of us are using a lot of devices. Mostly daily or more often. And once in a while a device becomes defective. A DVD-drive may fail due to age, the smartphone-screen may shiver, the battery starts to hold less and less energy, a button needs to be pressed harder every time before it stops working at all, the keyboard starts to become skittish after you spilled a caffeinated beverage on it, the contact of a connector may become unreliable, …

A few years ago, when people used mainly desktop computers, that was no big deal. You bought a new part end replaced it. Opening up a case was not complicated and most thinks were built to be replaced by the user or everyone who was a little curious. But nowadays it is different. For several reasons. Devices have become smaller, lighter and more functions are stuffed into one case. Also, making things easy to repair lowers your profit as a company twice, because designing and building gets more expensive and if you can repair your device you will buy less new ones.

Come if you just want to see, what a device is actually made of, if you want to learn how to open one yourself in a proper way or even how to repair your broken device.

Bring yourself:
Everyone is welcome. No experience or knowledge is needed. Almost everyone can do these things. Calm hands are good, so try to consume not to much (or enough if you are very addicted : ) caffeine in advance. „Rummackern“ (= dominant behaviour, playing THE specialist, mansplaining, …) will not be tolerated.

Bring your own devices:
Feel very free to bring your own devices. You can bring all kinds of devices. Smartphones, laptops, tablets, radios, monitors, …
If you want to repair it, ask here first, if you going to need a replacement part. Usually broken plastic can be glued, a broken digitizer (the touch-part of a touchscreen) must be replaced as well as a broken display (the monitor of a touchscreen) or old batteries. If needed, buy a replacement part (ebay is a good place, consider the shipping times!) and bring it with you. Parts are often cheap (a typical smartphone digitizer is around 15 Euro, a typical display between 15 and 30 Euro and both in one set between 30 and 50 Euro. A battery might cost around 10 Euro). If you do not know, what you need, just name your device and describe its defect here in the comment section.

Bring your own tools:
I do have some tools, but I will not have an indefinite number of them. If you have small screwdrivers, bring them with you. Bring as well small plastic things as a plectrum, a ruler or the SD-card dummy from your laptop. We will use them as spudges. And bring whatever you think would be necessary.

Disclaimer:
I will not be liable for any damage you, I or others do to your devices, yourself, others or others’ devices. But I will try my very best not to break anything and to help you to avoid breaking anything. So far I never added any defects to a device I tried to repair or opened, but I cannot and will not guarantee that for the future. You lose your warranty on most devices if you open them. It is also harder to prove your gesetzlichen Gewährleistungsanspruch if you opened your device.
name: Opening and repairing (mobile) hardware
