description:
Tech learners unite! ;) The learners meetup is our place to explore tech topics, get help on the questions that block our learning progress & meet like-minded learners to get inspired, share experiences or even join forces to learn together. The motto is "everybody is a learner", so no matter what level you are on, this meetup invites you to follow your curiosity and explore new areas.

The meetup features: Certified 100% jargon-free talks about tech fundamentals, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups on your most burning questions related to these topics. 

Agenda
-----------

Talk: AfricaHackTrip (ca. 15 mins) – A few months ago a bunch of European hackers made a trip to Africa to explore the tech scene, to exchange, collaborate and connect the communities. We hosted Barcamps and Hackathons in Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda and Tanzania, met at least 400 tech people interested in topics like open-source, web development, community, mobile apps, UX… Community-driven education has also been a topic and we even founded the OTS Nairobi chapter! I’d like to tell you a little bit about it. Maybe also about the crazy life you can lead as a "hacker" ;) http://africahacktrip.org

Martin is a web developer focussing on frontend and user interfaces currently freelancing. He is co-organizing the OTS Learners Meetup, JavaScript workshops and JavaScript Learners Groups and thinks most of the apps around should be HTML5.

Talk: Your first open source contribution (ca. 10 mins) - Getting started with contributing to open source can
seem very intimidating at first. This talk shows how to pick your first project and get started with contributing.

Philipp is a recent graduate from the OTS Hackership programme where he has been focusing on learning about Ruby on Rails and Test Driven Development.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 45 mins) - Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
name: Learners Meetup

description:
Creative Coding Stammtisch (formerly known as Processing Stammtisch) is a friendly gathering of Creative Coders who like to work with programs such as Processing, openFrameworks, SuperCollider, Pure Data, vvvv, Arduino, Cinder, etc. The atmosphere is relaxed. There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions.

It is free and open to artists, designers, and code enthusiasts, regardless of age, gender or programming level. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome and free to ask questions. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stammtisch

Please note that there will be no formal talks and no lesson but many interesting people to talk to and get inspiration from.

What should I bring? 
Bring your computer. Snacks are also a good idea :)

Where is it? 
Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

The place is a bit hard to find. This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking
name: Creative Coding Stammtisch

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We are in the 3rd or 5th floor, please check the signs
name: Continuous Python Learning Group

description:
This is a Javascript Learning group meeting up every Wednesday.

Bring your laptop and the project that you are working on and there, there will be some coaches whom ask and able to help, but we also learn from each other.

You can already see from the RSVP List who are the coaches and contact them directly. 

The target is beginners/medium, people that are just approaching Javascript are welcome to come, discover and try out as well as who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with Javascript related topics.

Please note there will be no talks, no lesson, just people love coding together and keep learning :)

If you don't have any project in mind or anything currently working on, don't worry,there are already materials made for the Javascript beginners workshop which is free and open. You can have a look here: Day1 - Day2 Maybe you can also help us to improve the material! ;)

description:
Come together to hack together on your own stuff.

Every Saturday afternoon can be your dedicated project time. Be it your work from the week, the pet project, your new start-up or "just" the next lessons on codeacademy - sit down and get cracking. Why not do that at home? Because this will be a hangout for all kinds of people and so you can chat in your breaks, get to know new people and help each other out when you're stuck.

Although it's announced on our meetup group a few things to note about this meetup:

It's not guaranteed you'll have a OTS member/coach present. There won't be any prepared talks or workshops. There are other people and music, too. Also the WIFI is flaky sometimes. We are offering this as an easier way to meet other learners. Please ping us if you have suggestions to make this event more useful to you all.

The first one to come, put up a paper easily visible for everyone, stating that there is the OTS Learners hangout so that others can find you.
how_to_find_us: We'll meet in the café downstairs, Look for some friendly people with laptops.

description:
OpenTechSchool will officially take over the hosting and organisation of IT-Labs Berlin and kicks it off together with Technologie Stiftung Berlin, the Freien Universität Berlin, the Technischen Universität Berlin, the Hochschule für Wirtschaft und Technik, KDAB Deutschland and Immobilienscout24. You want to learn more about the event, what IT-Labs is and does and what the future at OpenTechSchool will bring it, please refer to this blog post.

This event will be in German only (it's an official thing).

Schedule (german):

15:30 Uhr Ankommen
15:45 Uhr Begrüßung
16:00 Uhr Vorträge (Themen: Informatikdidaktik, Nachwuchsförderung im MINT-Bereich, außerschulische Angebote, Schülerlabore)
17:00 Uhr Networking und Ausstellung (diverse Projekte, sowie freie Lehr- und Lernmaterialien)
17:30 Uhr geplantes Ende der Veranstaltung

Please see this blog post for all the details and if you'd like to join please also RSVP via this form.

description:
It's never been easier to make video games, thanks to the multitude of resources available and a growing worldwide community willing to help beginners. As a result, new games are being released every day, exploring different directions and tackling novel themes: playing is more stimulating and inclusive than ever.

Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level. If you like video games, we'll make sure you have a good time!

The event is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks (5 to 15 minutes), followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge.

2. PLAY: games made or chosen by the speakers will be shown; in addition, all participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and maybe find collaborators.

To give you a better idea of what you're going to find, check out the summaries of the previous Talk & Play: #1, #2, #3, #4 

The Talk & Play #5 speakers will be:

— Pedro Lopes, a PhD student of Prof. Patrick Baudisch's Human Computer Interaction lab in Hasso Plattner Institut, Berlin. Pedro investigates the future of interfaces, such as muscle-interfaces. A believer on the unification of art and research, often gives talks about it [BodyControlled, Campus Party 2013]. Makes and writes music using turntables [in eitr] and writes about music too [in jazz.pt magazine]. 

Talk Abstract: Muscle-Propelled Games: playing games through our bodies

Our research points out that "feeling forces" is the next step for increased realism in human computer interfaces, and a way of creating very small mobile devices. For a long time, the key to immersion in interactive experience and games was sought in photorealistic graphics. Now, interfaces and games became more immersive by requiring us to physically enact, such as with Wii or Kinect. With graphics and user interaction now part of many games, many researchers argue that haptics and motion are the next step towards increasing realism. However, when it comes to output, we have nothing more than vibrating buzzers, such as the ones that make our smartphones vibrate. In this talk, we show compelling new ultra-mobile technologies that provide exciting haptic feedback. Our approaches achieve a low hardware footprint by leveraging use our own muscle power! We will demonstrate several projects that allow for interaction to become more immersive.  More info | Video preview

— Sjors Houkes has supported starting game studios for years at Dutch Game Garden, by organising network events, festivals and game jams. He wants to get good at making games himself, but for the moment is way more capable as a professional voice actor. His talk is titled Playing the Jam Game:

Game jamming is hot. All the hip devs do it. In the last ten years, the number of jams has risen to the amount that there's always a jam going on, whether online or local, and anyone is welcome to join. Lately, even scandals like the Candy trademark and Flappy Bird are popular jam material. But why? Why spend time with strangers, on projects that hardly ever get a release? What is the nature of a jam? And how can we use it to our advantage? Let's take a step back and talk about it.

— Giles Coope, Javier Díaz and Raphaël de Courville teamed up for the second year in a row to create a game during the Global Game Jam in Berlin. The result was にゃんこわん (Nyanko-Wan), a kawaii local multiplayer crowd game meant to be played by cats. They will tell us more about its development and then we're all (=all people with a touch screen device) going to play the game together.

On top of this, Lorenzo will talk a bit about A MAZE. / Berlin 2014 which is going to take place on April 9-11 – he's involved in the organisation of the festival and uses every available opportunity to promote it. By the way: have you bought a ticket already? Have you submitted your game for the awards? The deadline is February 15!

During the Play part of the evening some of the games made during the Global Game Jam Berlin 2014 will be shown, but as always all participants are invited to bring their own creations.

Would you like to give a talk as well in the future? Then get in touch!

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #5

description:
Join us for the 3rd Edition of the Physical Computing Club where the topic for this meeting will be: motors! So Kanno will be our lovely guest hacker, telling us about his previous cool projects w/motors as well as how you can use them to do cool things in your own projects!

What is it? ~ The physical computing club is a monthly gathering open to all enthusiasts to tinker, hack and collaborate on hardware projects and share our experiences.

Every meeting will have a theme and will feature a “maker in house” to inspire us with a lighting talk on the theme of the day, and help us learning new hardware and coding tricks.

Note: this an advanced topic hack day, not a workshop, and as such not very suitable for beginners. (If you’re a complete beginner in physical computing don’t be scared, OTS will be giving an “Intro to Arduino Workshop” that will give you the chance to feel comfortable with the basics of electronics and creative coding! Look for a beginner workshop to take place early on in the new year!)

Details If you can’t find the Fablab please call: 0176 20504057 or Rachel at 0176 995 88 920.

Feel free to bring snacks! Also note: we ask that all participants donate 1€/2€ to our host, FabLab Berlin for use of their great hackerspace!

See you all Sunday!
name: Physical Computing Club-- 3.0

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with 1-2 easy-to-understand talks on tech, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda
-----------

Talk: AfricaHackTrip (ca. 15 mins) – A few months ago a bunch of European hackers made a trip to Africa to explore the tech scene, to exchange, collaborate and connect the communities. We hosted Barcamps and Hackathons in Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda and Tanzania, met at least 400 tech people interested in topics like open-source, web development, community, mobile apps, UX… Community-driven education has also been a topic and we even founded the OTS Nairobi chapter! I’d like to tell you a little bit about it. Maybe also about the crazy life you can lead as a "hacker" ;) http://africahacktrip.org

Martin is a web developer focussing on frontend and user interfaces currently freelancing. He is co-organizing the OTS Learners Meetup, JavaScript workshops and JavaScript Learners Groups and thinks most of the apps around should be HTML5.

Talk: „Anatomy of a web request“ (ca. 15 mins) - Did you ever wonder what happens after you entered a URL into your browser? This talk presents the anatomy of a web request. You'll learn what is sent to and received from the server, including such magical things like cookies and how this might effect your privacy.

Andreas is technical lead at Moccu, a digital agency based in Berlin. Most of the time he uses Python and Django to build backend systems for websites and web applications. He also likes to tweak the agency's workflow with various tools and techniques. At OpenTechSchool Andreas is mainly engaged in the Python group where he organizes workshops and contributes to the learning materials

A mini barcamp! (ca. 45 mins) - Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
hi Everyone,

We are planning to dedicate March to creating more learning material for kids workshops but adults could also learn from this material, too!

We specifically will work on creating learning material to teach coding to kids! We're thinking of programs easier to grasp for kids such as Scratch or Processing-- who is interested to join in? 

Here are the dates:
Saturday, March 8, 12-4pm, Betahaus Cafe (tomorrow!)
Saturday, March 15, 12-4pm, Betahaus Cafe
Saturday, March 22, 12-4pm, Betahaus Cafe
Saturday, March 29, 12-4pm, Betahaus Cafe

Alternative dates would be:
Tues. March 11, 7-9pm, Co-up mtg. rm, 5th flr.
Tues. March 18 7-9pm, Co-up mtg. rm, 5th flr.
Tues. March 25 7-9pm, Co-up mtg. rm, 5th flr.

if you would like to contribute in any way-- either helping out with material for Scratch/Processing or if you know of another technology which kids can easily pick up and which you would like to contribute to, please get in touch!

By the way, we're aiming for enough material for 4hr. workshops.

 Sorry for the late notice but hope to see some of you there! Feel free to write if you have questions: rachel@opentechschool.org

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly collaborative computational art event. It is free and open to all, regardless of age, gender, or previous experience. Please read the following description before you join! You will enjoy it more.

What is this event? 
A relaxed (but intense) prototyping day. Participants are encouraged to form teams, improvise and create something together in a limited time. Asking questions throughout the day is encouraged!

Who is this event for?
Artists (New Media or otherwise), technologists, designers, makers, and code enthusiasts of all kinds. If you are creative and like a bit of challenge, this one is for you. 

What this event is not.
The Creative Code Jam is not a lesson, a contest or a conference.

What is Creative Coding?
Creative coding is the art of expressing oneself through the medium of computation.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer or other computational weapon of choice. Interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials and snacks to share are also always a good idea :)

Theme suggestion
Please suggest a theme in the comments below. Themes can be random topics like "cake", "resilience" or "killer clowns", creative constrains like "make a computational version of a non-digital artpiece", or anything you can think of really.

Where is it?
co.up coworking
Adalbertstr. 8
10999 Berlin

The place is a bit hard to find. 
This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking

Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

description:
/***/  SCROLL DOWN FOR UPDATES!!!  /***/

Hello world!

Arduino is turning 10 years old and all over the world the maker community will meet to celebrate its birthday http://day.arduino.cc

Time has come to celebrate physical computing and hardware hacking, with blinking LEDs, noisy buzzers and rebellious motors!

In Berlin the PhysicalComputingClub is planning a full afternoon of hacking, demos and intro sessions to the Arduino platform in collaboration with OpenTechSchool, betahaus, TinkerSoup and Afrimakers.

The event is open to everyone, no age limit, no pre-requisites.
Did you just hear about Arduino and want to know more? Did you attend a workshop and want to meet fellow enthusiasts? Or you want to join a challenge to create a working project in 4 hours? Or maybe you just want to get inspired by other makers projects?
This event is for you! 

We will host  15min. intro sessions every hour for newbies and curious, a full speed hackathon for makers and a show and tell where experienced makers will share their projects.

Plus, the awesome people at TinkerSoup will offer a prize for the best hack!

Here’s a schedule of the event:
14:00 – Arduino Day and ‘Arduino On Speed’ Hackathon kick off
14:30 – ‘Arduino On Speed’ Hackathon starts
15:00 – Intro to Arduino session
16:00 – Intro to Arduino session
17:00 – Intro to Arduino session
18:00 – Intro to Arduino session
18:30 – ‘Arduino On Speed’ Hackathon ends
18:45 – Hackathon demos
19:15 – Arduino makers show and tell

• FORK-O-DRUMBOT (Vito Caiata)

• AFRIMAKERS (Stefania Druga)

• TRAFOPOP (Stefan Hintz) 

• MICROFLO (Jon Nordby)

• TeeOnArdu (Georg Werner)

So, come and join the Berlin maker community at betahaus next Sat 29th of March!

PS: do you have an awesome Arduino-based project you want to show? contact us at rachel@opentechschool.org
name: Physical Computing Cl­ub presents ARDUINO DAY!

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with 1-2 easy-to-understand talks on tech, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda
-----------

Talk: Brown Dogs and Barbers - Explaining computer science to everybody! (ca. 15 mins)

Computers are a huge part of our everyday lives but most of us have little or no idea about the science behind them. I am writing a book, Brown Dogs and Barbers, which will introduce computer science to everyday readers and take them on a fascinating journey through the story of computing. I will talk about the ideas behind the book, the writing/publishing process, and how you can get involved.

Karl Beecher is an academic turned startup founder and works as a company director, software engineer, teacher and author.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins) - Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly collaborative computational art event. It is free and open to all, regardless of age, gender, or previous experience. Please read the following description before you join! You will enjoy it more.

What is this event? 
A relaxed (but intense) prototyping day. Participants are invited to form teams, improvise and create something together in a limited time. Asking questions throughout the day is encouraged!

What is Creative Coding?
Creative coding is the art of expressing oneself through the medium of computation. Creative coders often use tools like Processing, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, etc.

Who is this event for?
Artists (New Media or otherwise), technologists, designers, makers, and code enthusiasts of all kinds. If you are creative and like a bit of challenge, this one is for you. 

What this event is not.
The Creative Code Jam is not a lesson, a contest or a conference.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer or other computational weapon of choice. Interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials and snacks to share are also always a good idea :)

Theme suggestion
Please suggest a theme in the comments below. Themes can be random topics like "cake", "resilience" or "killer clowns", creative constrains like "make a computational version of a non-digital artpiece", or anything you can think of really.

Where is it?
co.up coworking
Adalbertstr. 8
10999 Berlin

The place is a bit hard to find. 
This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking

Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
The workshop will focus on the programming and creation process of a simple mobile Augmented Reality (AR) application on Android smartphones. You will be introduced into the usage of helpful AR frameworks and during the workshop will create your very own, first 3D Augmented Reality Android App. After you'll be able to understand the characteristics of the technology behind mobile AR applications and the challenges of building such apps. 

Prior Java Development Skills are required and experience with Android Development environment is definitely helpful.

And don't forget to bring:

• a recent Android device (4.0+) with a Camera

• a Laptop with set up Android Developer Environment of Eclipse+SDK

RSVPs open April 8, 2014 Tuesday 6:00pm (Berlin Time). Seats are limited so please keep the RSVP up to date. We are still looking for coaches to be able to host more people, if you'd like to help us coach, please let us know via posting here.

The cover picture is a cut-out of this wiki commons picture.
how_to_find_us: We are on the 3rd floor
name: [Workshop] Augmented Reality with Android

description:
In this workshop you will be introduced to the social side of coding. We will therefore use the most popular site for social programming: GitHub.
The weapon of our choice will be Git, a Source Code Management (SCM) tool. This tool keeps a copy of every version of a file in your repository - wether it is code or an important paper.

The course itself is going to have to parts. In the first part we will get you up and running with Git and GitHub. You will create a simple repository and get it on GitHub. During the second half we will show you some of the really neat things you can do with GitHub.
We will welcome you to the Underground - a secret organisation planning world domination. Here you will help us to create a list of the best cafes, bars and restaurants around the globe. After all: Nobody wants to take over the world with an empty stomach.

RSVPs will open on April 16, 2014 Wednesday. Unfortunately the Underground only can accommodate a limited number of people, so please keep the list up to date. We are still looking for people to help us coach. If you
are interested in helping people get started with Git, please let us know with a posting in this discussion. (link to here: http://discourse.opentechschool.org/t/call-for-coaches-git-workshop-in-berlin/494/2)
name: Workshop: Taking over the world with GitHub – An Intro to social coding

description:
Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level: if you like video games, we'll make sure you have a good time!

The event is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks (5 to 15 minutes), followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge

2. PLAY: All participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and, who knows?, maybe find collaborators for future projects

Check out the summaries of the previous events to get a better idea of what we talk about when we talk about video games.

The speakers this time will be:

Daniel Finck, co-founder and product manager of Berlin based Pfeffermind Games, is going to talk about their upcoming release of the location based mobile game Spyday. Spyday is a mixture of geocaching, quiz and strategy game where every player controls a team of virtual spies that he can place all around the city to steal points from others.

Maschinen-Mensch UG, a small game studio recently founded by the former triple-A developers Riad Djemili and Johannes Kristmann. They’re currently developing their first independently produced title The Curious Expedition, a roguelike expedition-sim set in the 19th century. The talk will be focused on their way from the triple-A industry to becoming an independent developer and the creation of The Curious Expedition, its design goals and technical background.

Would you like to give a talk, at this event or in the future? Then get in touch! 

NEU! Talk & Play now has its own @TalkAndPlay_ Twitter account. And don't forget to sign up to the newsletter!

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #6

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with 1-2 easy-to-understand talks on tech, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda
-----------

Talk: Code is read many more times than written (ca. 15 mins)

What do software engineers d all day long? Write code? Of course!  But isn't it more about reading? About understanding what's happening? I believe so, that's why we should put an extra effort into writing code that is as understandable as possible.

This talk is about techniques that will help you write more  readable code, be more productive and have more fun!"

Tobi is a clean coder, Rubyist, learner, teacher and agile craftsman by passion. He organizes the Ruby User Group Berlin and contributes to shoes and hacketyhack. He has a special neck for teaching, which is why he is a frequent coach at Rails Girls Berlin and also started to teach a course at a university.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins) - Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
Interested in attending Hackership as a learner or a coach but unsure whether it's your thing? Want to try it out first before committing to a three months programme? Then this is your chance.

A Taste of Hackership comes to the rescue. We'll come together and give you a peak into what our programme exactly looks like. Whether you want to coach or learn, giving you the chance to experience first hand what Hackership is.  Getting your questions about the programme answered while learning something new and cool Hackership-style. So bring your laptop and get ready to hack!

For Hackership batch-1 we will have an emphasis on "multimedia and the web". For those interested in that topic that means you will have coaches and workshops specialised on that very subject during batch-1. And we'll get you started exploring it during this Taste session already!

But that does not mean you can not join Hackership with another learning topic. As before we welcome and will support learners with other learning goals too. If that's the case bring whatever else you want to learn to this Taste session, and we'll be ready to answer any questions you have and will suggest some pre-Hackership learning projects to get you ready. 

If you can't make it this time, you have other chances to experience it:

• Thursday, May 22nd from 7:30 p.m.

• Thursday, May 29th from 7:30 p.m.

• Saturday, June 7th 2-6 p.m.

• Tuesday, June 10th 12a.m.-6p.m.

To learn more about Hackership, also:

• check out our blog

• join the newsletter

• watch our intro video

• get your questions answered
name: A Taste of Hackership #1

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with 1-2 easy-to-understand talks on tech, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda
-----------

Talk: »The Hitchhikers Guide to the Internet«
I will explain how the internet and the world wide web work, what the difference between the two is and why you should care. We'll go from ones and zeros all the way up to animated cat pictures!

John is a backend developer at Wooga, 15 years member of Chaos Computer Club, Podcaster, Lecturer at the University of Arts (6th year), administrator, sometimes event organizer (Euruko 2011), Discordian and generally curious.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins) - Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
how_to_find_us: This time, we will  be at our usual place in the 3rd floor again! The place is a bit hard to find. This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking

The event is free and open to artists, designers, and code enthusiasts, regardless of age, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome and free to ask questions.

name: A Taste of Hackership #4

description:
Are you interested in node.js, but never got around to work with it?Are you maybe already using node-based things on the command line, and want to understand how they work?Do you want to see how you can use node.js to work with servers, files and other things? This is the workshop for you!

To participate in this workshop: you'll need to have some programming experience, JavaScript or other languages. We don't expect you to be a full-time programmer, but you should know what variables, loops and functions are, and how to use them. If you wanna refresh your JavaScript skills, have a look here:  http://opentechschool.github.io/js-beginners-4h-workshop-1/

During 2-3 hours on a Sunday afternoon, we'll get you set up with node, show you what node packages are and how to use them, and show you how to write a simple server application. 

You'll need to bring your own laptop for this course. Since node.js is a relatively short install, we can help you get set up (it runs on windows, mac and linux), but if you wanna come prepared, you can install it from http://nodejs.org/download/ (use the installer, it takes about 5 minutes).

The workshop is absolutely free, no charge, and there will be coaches speaking english, german and a bunch of other languages as well. 

Because the number of seats is limited, it is important that you only sign up if you definitely plan on coming (and do so, too!). If you can't make it for any reason, please cancel your attendance on Meetup right away so your someone on the waiting list can take your place. Thanks, and we look forward to seeing you there!
name: Node.js for beginners workshop

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly collaborative computational art event. It is free and open to all, regardless of age, gender, or previous experience. Please read the following description before you join! You will enjoy it more.

What is this event? 
A relaxed (but intense) prototyping day. Participants are invited to form teams, improvise and create something together in a limited time. Asking questions throughout the day is encouraged!

What is Creative Coding?
Creative coding is the art of expressing oneself through the medium of computation. Creative coders often use tools like Processing, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, etc.

Who is this event for?
Artists (New Media or otherwise), technologists, designers, makers, and code enthusiasts of all kinds. If you are creative and like a bit of challenge, this one is for you. 

What this event is not.
The Creative Code Jam is not a lesson, a contest or a conference.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer or other computational weapon of choice. Interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials and snacks to share are also always a good idea :)

Theme suggestion
Please suggest a theme in the comments below. Themes can be random topics like "cake", "resilience" or "killer clowns", creative constrains like "make a computational version of a non-digital artpiece", or anything you can think of really.

Where is it?
co.up coworking
Adalbertstr. 8
10999 Berlin

The place is a bit hard to find. 
This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking

Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
Talk & Play is turning one! To celebrate the occasion, this meetup is going to be a bit different than usual: it will take place in a special location featuring a beautiful garden, and there will be a BBQ as well, weather permitting – we're going to provide some food but it would be nice if you could bring extra stuff (file under: BYOF). UPDATE: because of the rainy and cold weather there won't be any BBQ, but the meetup is taking place anyway! Doors are at 6:30pm, Vescape’s presentation will start around 7:30pm. There will be drinks & snacks. Bring your games!

This time there will be no talks, but Jerome Feys and Jean-Baptiste Molle, the two founders of the VESCAPE game studio headquartered in the Blue Factory, are going to showcase their new concept. They develop interactive video games for fitness equipment like exercise bikes. Their first game, Vescape Cycle Racing, is a cycle racing game where the avatar bikes at the exact same speed as the player and the pedaling resistance changes automatically according to the slope, making it for example much harder to bike uphill. They will also present other games like Django Kart, a go-kart racing game, and some maze games as well as the possibilities for game developers to offer their own concepts and games on their platform.

As always, all participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and, who knows?, maybe find collaborators for future projects. 

If you've never been to Talk & Play before, check out the summaries of the previous events to get a better idea of what we talk about when we talk about video games.

Would you like to give a talk in the future? Then get in touch.

Oh by the way, have you heard about Join – 1st Local Multiplayer Summit that Lorenzo and Sjors are organising on August 9 in Berlin? Save the date and sign up to the newsletter to receive all the updates!

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
name: Talk & Play #7

description:
Want to learn more about the OpenTechSchool? Or want to contribute or discuss potential ideas, and even start planning them with us? Then join us for drinks every 4 weeks on Thursday evening.

The OpenTechSchool organisers will meet at 7:30p.m. at Co.up (5th floor) -- if you feel like contributing to that too you are welcome -- and then at 9p.m. we'll head for more discussions, planning and drinks in a bar or a park near Kottbusser Tor.

The specific location for those drinks will be different each time and decided a few days in advance and announced on this page.
how_to_find_us: We'll be most likely in the back of the bar where the old cinema chairs are
name: OpenTechSchool Drinks

description:
MicroFlo is an open source dataflow-runtime for microcontrollers (like Arduino),
which allows you to program in a visual, node-based manner - similar to tools like VVVV, Pure Data and Max MSP http://microflo.org. Unlike other visual tools that rely on having a computer attached at all times, a MicroFlo program runs standalone in the microcontroller.

MicroFlo uses Flowhub.io as its IDE. Flowhub can also be used to program JavaScript for browser and server.

Introduction: 2-3 hours

Background
- Core programming concepts
- Working with digital and analog I/O
- More complex I/O components: Temperature, LEDs, etc
- Adding new components
- Communicating with a computer and NoFlo

After the introduction session, we’ll move to an open hackfest. It will last as long as people hang around. We’ll cover whatever there is interest for, but here are some ideas:

- Expand the component library
- Adding support for new boards/microcontrollers to MicroFlo
- Hacking core MicroFlo, and Flowhub (the IDE)

No prior knowledge of MicroFlo, NoFlo or Flowhub is required. Some prior experience with Arduino, microcontrollers or basic programming recommended.

You need to bring:

- A laptop with Linux/OSX/Windows.
- (optional) Your own Arduino / microcontroller hardware

We have 20 Arduino kits for loan from OpenTechSchool Berlin and Technologiestiftung Berlin.

See you there!﻿
name: Workshop+Hackfest: Introduction to MicroFlo

description:
This is all about building things in the browser: HTML, CSS and lots of JavaScript.

We are a friendly group that meets every Wednesday (except the first Wednesday of the month when there  is the general Learners Meetup) to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or is happy to get some help. No matter if you are a total newbie or an expert, we want to learn from each other.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials instead. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

• JavaScript for Beginners 1

• JavaScript for Beginners 2

• Intro to HTML/CSS

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)

description:
with Carl Crowder and Benjamin Kampmann
In this the first public learning session of Hackership Batch-1 the coaches Carl and Ben will present you with common best practice in using the Git Version Control System – basic understanding of Git requried¹.

The presentation will explaining hands-on how to best commit, branch, merge and manage remotes, before we will take a peak look into more advanced features of git like stash, rebase and bisect. After presentations all participants are invited to ask questions and share their advise about using git on a daily basis. If there are more specific issues or questions, everyone is invited to bring their laptop and ask the coaches one-on-one over a drink after to get things sorted out.

Drinks will be provided by Zalando. Sign ups will open Thursday July 31 at 6pm and close Tuesday August 4th 4pm. Make sure to sign up with your real name otherwise security won't let you in.

¹ At minimum the learning from our course.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly collaborative computational art event. It is free and open to all, regardless of age, gender, or previous experience. Please read the following description before you join! You will enjoy it more.

What is this event? 
A relaxed (but intense) prototyping day. Participants are invited to form teams, improvise and create something together in a limited time. Asking questions throughout the day is encouraged!

What is Creative Coding?
Creative coding is the art of expressing oneself through the medium of computation. Creative coders often use tools like Processing, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, etc.

Who is this event for?
Artists (New Media or otherwise), technologists, designers, makers, and code enthusiasts of all kinds. If you are creative and like a bit of challenge, this one is for you. 

What this event is not.
The Creative Code Jam is not a lesson, a contest or a conference.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer or other computational weapon of choice. Interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials and snacks to share are also always a good idea :)

Theme suggestion
Please suggest a theme in the comments below. Themes can be random topics like "cake", "resilience" or "killer clowns", creative constrains like "make a computational version of a non-digital artpiece", or anything you can think of really.

Where is it?
co.up coworking
Adalbertstr. 8
10999 Berlin

The place is a bit hard to find. 
This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking

Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements.  Afterwards, we’ll end the day with celebratory drinks and socializing at co.up! 

Drinks can be purchased for cheap at the venue. As for food, details will be announced soon.

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are build and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the crazy experiments on Codepen.io or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and Open Tech School. We have experience in teaching workshops and organzing events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of Open Tech School and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website:  http://cssclasses.cssconf.eu/
name: CSSclasses

description:
Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level: if you like video games, we'll make sure you have a good time!

The event is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks (5 to 15 minutes), followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge

2. PLAY: All participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and, who knows?, maybe find collaborators for future projects

Check out the summaries of the previous events to get a better idea of what to expect.

We've got a very interesting mix of speakers and themes this time:

— Adam Streck, The LARPscape of the Czech Republic

"A good experience does not have to be positive. It must be strong."In the Czech Republic, LARPs are the thing. How serious we are about it can be seen for example here. In my talk, I will go swiftly through the history of the LARPs, touch on the current state of affairs and give some insight into how we started combining the live gaming with the digital one.

I have started organizing LARPs in 2005, basing the game on the world of Fallout games, which we had the option to set in the incredibly atmospheric locations of 15 years abandoned Russian military bases. Currently I focus on hard sci-fi settings with use of the contemporary technology.

— Miho Tanaka is the founder of AirMarkr and organizer of AR Berlin. She has worked with interactive technologies and mobile for over 6 years, and was a new technologies consultant to major brands such as BMW, MINI and Vodafone. 

AirMarkr is a mobile app that lets you draw in the air in 3D "realspace".  

— Jonah Burke is a New York-based independent programmer and co-founder of EXO Games. Previously, he worked at Microsoft and Big Think, where Bjarne Stroustrup signed his copy of The C++ Programming Language. He created The Darfur Wall, a project that raised $100,000 for Sudan, and has written the software behind several startups.

He’s going to talk about EXO: Arena, a local multiplayer game for iPhone inspired by the film Tron.

— The Game Yourself team will present their upcoming smartphone app that takes a 3D model of your head, allowing you to select your character with your own face inside any game.

— Last but not least, our friends from Game Science Center Berlin (see Talk & Play #2) are going to make a small announcement about the opening of their space on September 1st!

— LAST MINUTE ADDITION! There will also be a quick & dirty live musical performance by Alfred Ladylike on the ukulele! She will play her MMO-themed folk hit, Level Up, and provide details on how you can be involved in the LARP-tastic music video shoot in Berlin on September 7th.

Would you like to give a talk, at this event or in the future? Then get in touch! 

Talk & Play now has its own @TalkAndPlay_ Twitter account that you should definitely follow – and don't forget to sign up to the newsletter, to receive an email every month with tips about game-related stuff happening in the city.

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #8

description:
with Benoît Bleuzé and Haiko Schol

For the second public learning session of Hackership Batch-1 the coaches Benoît and Haiko will give you an introduction to Design Patterns. 

Have you ever heard the term "Design Patterns" being bandied around and wondered what those actually are? In this talk you will find out where the term comes from, how it applies to software development and why there are different patterns for different languages. Common patterns in C++ and Python will also be presented, and other languages will be covered when necessary and during Q&A.

Drinks will be provided by Zalando. Sign ups will close on Tuesday August 26th 1pm. Make sure to sign up with your real name otherwise security won't let you in.

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with 1-2 easy-to-understand talks on tech, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda

Talk/Demo (ca. 15 mins): Test Driven Development (short TDD) is a big topic these days. Writing the test before implementing the functionality comes with decent benefits. The most obvious one of course is a good test coverage. But the short development cycle also helps to focus on what is important right now. Furthermore tests make it more easy to write good code because they enforce a thought-out structure and enable you to refactor without worrying about breaking something. 

But how to get started with Test Driven Development? This session will demonstrate how to code a small program with tests first. The process can be applied easily to projects of all scale.

Andreas is technical lead at Moccu, a digital agency based in Berlin. His Background is building backend systems for websites and web applications with Python and Django. He also likes to tweak the agency's workflow with various tools and techniques. At OpenTechSchool Andreas is mainly engaged in the Python group where he coaches at workshops and contributes to the learning materials

The main talk will be followed by a short talk (ca. 5 mins) from Daniel Rios, who learns Python with OTS, about his experiences with TDD.


A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed. We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
A fun, hands-on full-day workshop open for everyone with no or little programming experience to learn the basics of JavaScript. After learning the very basics you will draw an animate things on the screen and eventually proceed to creating a slideshow using also HTML and CSS.

What you will learn: After the workshop you will know some basic programming techniques that are useful in other languages than JavaScript, too, and you will have an understanding how to develop for the browser and make things interactive.

What is happening: As in all OpenTechSchool workshops you should be able to work through our tutorial material on your own while there will be many friendly coaches around (like 1 coach for four learners) that are happy to help any time. We speak German and English and probably more :)

Already know some JavaScript? Please be a coach! Sign up here.

Material: You can check out the material here:

• German: Basics, Slide Show

• English: Basics, Slide show

What you need: Motivation to learn programming and a laptop (let us know if you can't bring one). Ideally you already have a browser like Chrome installed and a decent text editor like Sublime Text.

Costs: The workshop is free of charge. We do this for fun and because we think more people should get into programming. You will have the chance to donate to OpenTechSchool e.V. during the event.

Food/drinks: There are places to eat, but it'd would be awesome if we also had a little buffet, and everyone who can contribute brought some of their favorite snacks to share. Feel free to bring anything you like: fruits, veggies, salad, bread, cookies, nuts, etc.

If you have registered but can't make it to the workshop for any reason, please click that you are not coming so your spot can go to someone else! Also, if the list is already full, sign up for the waiting list. Depending on the amount of coaches, we might gonna raise the participants we can take later...

This event is part of <a>jsfest.berlin</a>, a week full of events around JavaScript and the browser. If you're interested in server-side JavaScript you should also check out the NodeSchool workshop the very next day.

First Tim Tepass will give you an insight on how you build a personal brand, which reflects on things you do best. This key concept will help you not only displaying what you are capable of but also increases your chances on the job market!

Then Rani Verschoor, Recruiter at Zalando Technology, will share her experiences and talk about what’s important from Zalando’s point of view. The talk will address Tipps & tricks regarding a high quality application, how to perform best within an interview, etc. It will be followed by a Q&A session, where you have the chance to ask your personal questions and get deeper insights.

Drinks will be provided by Zalando. Sign ups will close on Tuesday September 16th 1pm. Make sure to sign up with your real full name (as stated on your passport) otherwise security won't let you in.

description:
Hear ye, hear ye, an update!

At the beginning of the 21st century, the superhero has found her technology-based counterpart in a transhumanism that sees itself as an international, cultural and intellectual movement with the goal to improve human nature through the use of technology. The targeted life-form is the human machine, the cyborg, as a utopia of evolutionary and biologial technology through the fusion of body and technological prosthesis using techniques such as bio-hacking, body-modification and mind control.

This Saturday, Open Tech School invites Cyborg e.V., c-base and the art project earlyhumanadapter to work collaboratively with the attendees of the Creative Code Jam under the topic of "Transhuman".

****

The Creative Code Jam is a monthly collaborative computational art event. It is free and open to all, regardless of age, gender, or previous experience. Please read the following description before you join! You will enjoy it more.

What is this event? 
A relaxed (but intense) prototyping day. Participants are invited to form teams, improvise and create something together in a limited time. Asking questions throughout the day is encouraged!

What is Creative Coding?
Creative coding is the art of expressing oneself through the medium of computation. Creative coders often use tools like Processing, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, etc.

Who is this event for?
Artists (New Media or otherwise), technologists, designers, makers, and code enthusiasts of all kinds. If you are creative and like a bit of challenge, this one is for you. 

What this event is not.
The Creative Code Jam is not a lesson, a contest or a conference.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer or other computational weapon of choice. Interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials and snacks to share are also always a good idea :)

Where is it?

co.up coworking
Adalbertstr. 8
10999 Berlin

The place is a bit hard to find. 
This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking

Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

description:
We know. You are all curious to find out what went on during the 12 weeks of Hackership. You are anxious to meet our talented developers who just spend their summers becoming even better hackers.

Good news: the wait is over. Come hang with our learners and celebrate their achievements at the Hackership batch-1 graduation party.

Over the last 12 weeks our learners spent day and night building their projects, while getting familiar with a wide range of technologies. Some focused on data science, while others got busy learning web development with frameworks like Django, Angular.js, or Tornado. And, yet another group of learners discovered the wonderful world of data visualization, using (among others) D3/Javascript.

On this Sunday afternoon, we'd like to invite you see and chat with them about their work in a relaxed bar over music and drinks. Come join us!
name: Hackership Batch-1 Graduation Party

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with 1-2 easy-to-understand talks on tech, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda

Talk/Demo (ca. 15 mins): Learn to code: the edupunk way!

How to approach a do it yourself learning attitude? Why is it better in a collaborative environment?

In this session I will share with you my learning experience at Hackership, the self-directed, hands-on full-time code learning program.

Danila Pellicani is an Interaction Designer, edupunk enthusiast and pizza maker. 
She just finished Hackership Batch-1 focusing on HTML/CSS and Javascript and she's currently looking for new challenges.
When she's not in front of a screen she helps organizing tech hands-on workshops with OpenTechSchool.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level: if you like (video) games, we'll make sure you have a good time! 

The event is free to attend and is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks (5 to 15 minutes), followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge

2. PLAY: All participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and, who knows?, maybe find collaborators for future projects

Check the comments section below shortly before the event for the exact schedule, and have a look at the summaries of the previous events to get a better idea of what to expect.

We've got two talks this time:

— Nora Gantert and Mathias Wölfing will present “Children’s game //Kinderspiel // 小意思”, an art project initiated by iRRi ART in cooperation with Starkad Berlin. Over the last few months they’ve collected statements and reports, in order to shed light on childhood and how cultural imprint is given to us through games, books and songs. The focus of this project is on transcultural phenomena and people who now work in the arts in the German, Chinese and Arabic cultural sphere.

— Javier Díaz will talk about the ZX Spectrum, the popular 8-bit personal home computer which sparked the indie scene of the 80s in Spain.

Would you like to give a talk, at this event or in the future? Then get in touch! 

Talk & Play now has its own @TalkAndPlay_ Twitter account that you should definitely follow – and don't forget to sign up to the newsletter, to receive an email every month with tips about game-related stuff happening in the city.

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #9

description:
SQL databases are one of the most commonly used form of data storage. From storing inventories of online shops to data from scientific research or financial markets, SQL databases allow for a structured representation of huge amounts of data. The SQL language is used to obtain the desired information from the data. For example, all shop items bought by a particular customer in the last two months.

Who can participate in this event?

Anyone interested in using and understanding SQL. In particular for applications in business, finance, sociology, and other fields. No existing knowledge about databases or programming in general is required.

What should you bring?

A Computer. Windows, Mac, Linux are all fine. No need to install any software beforehand. The coaches will provide you with all necessary software as well as the sample data required for the tasks of the course.

To provide a better learning experience and a good learner-to-coaches ratio, spaces are limited to 30.

If you want to help out as a coach rather than attend the workshop, please get in touch with me at ellen@opentechschool.org
name: Workshop: Using SQL to obtain information from databases

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with 1-2 easy-to-understand talks on tech, learning and hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda

Talk/Demo (ca. 15 mins): Processing text with regular expressions

Regular expressions are search patterns that are used to process text or textlike data. Through a set of so called metacharacters, regular expressions can be a very powerful tool. They are implemented in a lot of programming languages as well as many programs ranging from command line tools to office software, so they can be useful for almost everyone. This talk will give you an overview how regular expressions are used and shows the basics to get started.

Andreas is technical lead at Moccu, a digital agency based in Berlin. Most of the time he uses Python and Django to build backend systems for websites and web applications. He also likes to tweak the agency's workflow with various tools and techniques. At OpenTechSchool Andreas is mainly engaged in the Python group where he organizes workshops and contributes to the learning materials

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

name: Learners Meetup

description:
"Why do I need a preprocessor?"

Preprocessors for CSS have become the industry standard and you'll be reading more and more about them all over the tech community. They're named LESS, Stylus or SASS. Preprocessors make CSS more flexible, maintainable and fill in where CSS has its limits and drawbacks. And the best thing is: you don't have to be a CSS pro to get started with SASS. If you know basic CSS then there is know reason to hold back in learning SASS.

In this speech I want to show you how to install SASS on your machine, then get into the basics and most useful features it offers, later on I will show some live coding examples and dive into understandable advanced features to point out the potential and extensibility of a preprocessor.

The goal is to motivate attendees to get going with a preprocessor to make everyones code lives easier.


Location

The event will take place in conference room 4 & 5 and offer space for about 70-80 people. Beer, Water and Mate will be sponsored by ImmobilienScout24.

About the host

My name is Ferdinand Vogler (@ferdinandvogler) and I'm a communication design student in fifth semester at HTW Berlin. I recently visited my first OpenTechSchool presentation and love the concept of OTS and would like to contribute to that.
name: CSS with superpowers - SASS!

description:
A new edition of our JavaScript for Absolute Beginners workshop. The workshop time will be from 11am to about 5:30pm (with a long break). If you have little or no programming experience and are interested in learning the basics of Javascript (and programming), feel free to sign up!

This time the workshop will take place at ThoughtWorks Werkstatt (@werkstattB). We thank them very much for letting us use their space and also for sponsering the drinks for this event.

What you will learn: After the workshop you will know some basic programming techniques that are useful in other languages than JavaScript, too, and you will have an understanding how to develop for the browser and make things interactive.

Schedule:

• The doors open around 10.30am

• The workshop starts at 11am with a short overview, what the OpenTechSchool is and does and what you can learn on this day

• There will be a long break for lunch around 1:30pm. This will be about 1 hour.

• Towards the end of the workshop we might have a demo-round, where you can show what you created.

• The official end of the workshop will be around 5pm

Material: You can check out the material here: 

• Programming basics/introduction: English, German

• Create a photo gallery: English, German 

Share your results: https://titanpad.com/nwwQQhddrP

What you need: Motivation to learn programming and a laptop (let us know if you can't bring one). Please install the browser Chrome and the text editor Sublime Text.

Costs: The workshop is free of charge. We do this for fun and because we think more people should get into programming. You will have the chance to donate to OpenTechSchool e.V. during the event.

Food/drinks:  ThoughtWorks is not only sponsoring the space, but is also providing something to drink. Yay!

In the long lunch break you can go somewhere nearby and to eat something. We also would love to have a buffet of shared food at the workshop. At previous workshops it looked like this: https://twitter.com/OTS_BLN/status/511094273786523648. If you like this idea, feel free to bring some of your favourite snacks. Like fruits, veggies, salad, bread, cookies, nuts, etc.

Social Media: If you want to talk about the workshop at twitter you can use the hashtag #jsfab. We are @OTS_BLN there and ThoughtWorks Werkstatt is @WerkstattB.
If you are writing blog and post an article about your experience at the workshop, please let us know by sending a link to it.

Registration: We have already the capacity that we can host at this workshop.

If you have registered but can't make it to the workshop for any reason, please click that you are not coming so your spot can go to someone else!
name: Javascript for Absolute Beginners Workshop

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly collaborative computational art event. It is free and open to all, regardless of age, gender, or previous experience. Please read the following description before you join! You will enjoy it more.

What is this event? 
A relaxed (but intense) prototyping day. Participants are invited to form teams, improvise and create something together in a limited time. Asking questions throughout the day is encouraged!

What is Creative Coding?
Creative coding is the art of expressing oneself through the medium of computation. Creative coders often use tools like Processing, OpenFrameworks, Cinder, etc.

Who is this event for?
Artists (New Media or otherwise), technologists, designers, makers, and code enthusiasts of all kinds. If you are creative and like a bit of challenge, this one is for you. 

What this event is not.
The Creative Code Jam is not a lesson, a contest or a conference.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer or other computational weapon of choice. Interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials and snacks to share are also always a good idea :)

Theme suggestion
Please suggest a theme in the comments below. Themes can be random topics like "cake", "resilience" or "killer clowns", creative constrains like "make a computational version of a non-digital artpiece", or anything you can think of really.

Where is it?
co.up coworking
Adalbertstr. 8
10999 Berlin

The place is a bit hard to find. 
This should help: http://how.do/guide/get-to-coup-coworking

Co.up coworking is kindly providing the space. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
We're running a short series of Tinker Nights at FabLab Berlin beginning next Thursday. The upcoming theme is: BlinkingLight++

The intention is to go a step beyond your arduino intro course. This will not be a workshop but rather a hands-on night to tinker with your fellow arduino / electronics enthusiasts.

The format will include a brief intro to the theme for the evening, and then tinkering will commence! People can work alone or in pairs. Afterwards we'll do a quick show and tell of what people worked on, where they ran into problems, what they learned, etc. Fun times!

While there may be a few electronics components to borrow for the evening, ideally everyone should bring your own electronics to tinker with. Check out Tinkersoup if you're in need of placing an order: https://www.tinkersoup.de/

Spaces are limited, so sign up soon and see you there!

description:
Talk & Play is a bi-monthly meetup whose goal is to give a better idea of what it's like to create and play games today, providing the opportunity to local independent game makers to showcase their work in a friendly and relaxed environment. Everybody's welcome, whatever their background and knowledge level: if you like (video) games, we'll make sure you have a good time! 

The event is free to attend and is split into two parts:

1. TALK: 2/3 short game-related talks (5 to 15 minutes), followed by a Q&A session – it's all about sharing knowledge

2. PLAY: All participants are welcome to bring games they've made or are still working on – a perfect opportunity to discover and play new games, collect feedback and, who knows?, maybe find collaborators for future projects

Check the comments section below shortly before the event for the exact schedule, and have a look at the summaries of the previous events to get a better idea of what to expect.

So, who's going to speak at the last Talk & Play of the year?

— Eric Jannot is creative director of the startup waza. He will talk about news games and present their recent release No Male Heroes, a perfect example of this genre. 

— Alper Cugun is an engineer and partner at Hubbub, a Dutch/German design studio that helps people make new things to play with. He will show us a preview of Bycatch, an hybrid card game about drone warfare and surveillance that Hubbub is developing together with Subalekha Udayasankar. The game touches on a heavy theme but still allows everybody to determine their on experience (and there's a great gimmick with smartphones).

—Luca Lombardo likes games and is doing the first steps towards founding his game publishing startup Giant Breath. Christiaan Janssen makes games in jams and sometimes outside of jams too. Their talk is titled “Genres Limit Creativity" and will be about the influence of genres in the game design process.

Would you like to give a talk, at this event or in the future? Then get in touch! 

Talk & Play now has its own @TalkAndPlay_ Twitter account that you should definitely follow – and don't forget to sign up to the newsletter, to receive an email every month with tips about game-related stuff happening in the city.

Talk & Play is organised in collaboration with the monthly Berlin Mini Game Jam and A MAZE.
how_to_find_us: 3rd floor
name: Talk & Play #10

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Agenda

Talk (ca. 20 mins): Tech presentations can be great presentations!

Presentations are how we share knowledge, or promote our projects and ideas to others. We want our audience to enjoy and remember what we tell them. Learn some tips on how to become a better presenter from someone who has studied the art.

Matteo Cassese is a consultant and entrepreneur passionate about innovation. He's been playing with the intertubes since 1993 as web developer and system administrator and has been blogging since 2001. He's the founder of  La Fabbrica della Realtà and the author of Presentation Hero, an innovative presentation training system.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
We're running a short series of Tinker Nights at FabLab Berlin. This will be the last night of the series. The upcoming theme is Softwaves.

Here you reinforce the basics, usage of the serial port, and learn how mix things up! Capacitive clothes: touch a piece of cloth to switch on an LED. Resistive clothes: stretch a piece of cloth and see the brightness of an LED changing. Buzzer: play a melody with a Piezo speaker. Connecting to Software: processing. (Please download and install beforehand).

description:
The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby). 

We are a friendly group that meets every Monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop, although additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them. 

Sometimes, we have some short talk on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. These are good ones we can recommend: 

• The Ruby Koans (very succinct)

• The Rails Tutorial by M. Hartl (very extensive, also covers tests and git)

• Interactive tutorials at the Ruby Monk 

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

If you are a coach, organizer, or want to help the learners, please make a post on discourse so that we can add you to a separate list.
how_to_find_us: Enter the first back-yard, there's a door on the right. Fairmondo's office is on the first floor. If the door doesn't open easily: Try the white button for wheel-chair users to the left of the door.

name: Learners Meetup

description:
A message from the team

Dear creative coders,

Our next Berlin meetup — the fifteenth Creative Coding Stammtisch — is coming up this Friday night at co.up. It is is a friendly gathering of artists, designers, students, academics, researchers and anyone interested in the use of technology as a medium. It’s a place to grow and share your passion for generative design, new media, net.art, etc. Everyone is welcome and free to present a project, propose a topic for discussion or even sit back and enjoy the conversation.

But we are not (only) writing to promote our event. The main reason we're putting this down is because up to now — we're ashamed to admit — our meetups have suffered from a gender bias not reflecting what we know to be the real diversity of the Art and Technology scene of Berlin.

As members of Open Tech School as well as individually, our team has always been committed to supporting diversity. But it's not enough to be well-meaning and we've come to realize we need to be more vocal about what we stand for. We can do better and, from today on, we are going to.

We want people of any gender, origin, belief system, sexual orientation or knowledge level to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are reaching out to female artists/designers/theorists/students/learners to let you know that you DO belong and are part of it. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard.

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or an expert, a theorist or a practicing artist/technologist, we invite you to join us on Friday, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. Together, we can make our gatherings the diverse and supportive network they were always meant to be.

Ps: Though the main focus of this post is to address the gender bias, it goes without saying that our invitation extends to anyone who feels underrepresented in Art & Tech events.

The Creative Code Berlin team
Raphaël de Courville
Rachel Uwa
Abe Pazos
Ramin Soleymani

--

Creative Code Stammtisch

is a friendly gathering of creative people who like to work with programs such as Processing, openFrameworks, SuperCollider, Pure Data, vvvv, Arduino, Cinder, etc. The atmosphere is relaxed. There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions.

The event is free and open to artists, designers, and code enthusiasts, regardless of age, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome and free to ask questions. Please note that there will be no formal talks and no lesson but many interesting people to talk to and get inspiration from.

What should I bring?
Bring your computer. Stuff to show if you can. Snacks are also a good idea :)

Where is it?
Co-up Coworking space
Adalbertstr. 7-8
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes)

How much is it?
Attending this event is free, like all OpenTechSchool events! Co-up is kindly providing the space. If you feel grateful (we certainly do), you can thank them buying their drinks for €1.50! 

Do I need to know German?
Our events are in English. International guests are more than welcome!

See you there!
name: Creative Code Stammtisch #15
