description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. 

Creations can range from live visuals and custom VJing tools to visual art and generative design, art installations, net.art, interactive art, projection mapping, sound art and much more.

Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation, so making mistakes is not only okay, it's actually encouraged!

And you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! :) If you think you might enjoy building machines that make art, you will have fun!

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/

During the jam, participants from various backgrounds are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. We also often propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. If there is interest, we may give short a introduction on a topic related to creative coding. The format is open so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :)

SAFE SPACE POLICY

The Creative Code Jam is free and open to all, regardless of gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation or religion. We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

The full text of our Safe Space Policy can be found at: http://tinyurl.com/safespacepolicy.

<a href="https://github.com/SableRaf/CCBerlin/tree/master/SafeSpacePolicy"></a>


WHAT SHOULD I BRING? 

Bring your imagination, your computer, interesting books for inspiration, fancy hardware, quirky materials, etc. Snacks to share are also always a good idea :)


DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?

We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German :)

WHERE IS IT? 

Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are kindly providing the space for free. You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): You Too Can be a Web Server

What actually happens when we visit a website? Browsers have millions of lines of code and servers have fancy service-oriented-architectures with dozens of components, so where do we start?

Fortunately, we have amazing tools to help us. We can bypass the complexity of browsers and servers, and simply examine the communication between them – no programming knowledge necessary! We'll use these tools and look at the underlying patterns shared across the entire web, from the simplest static pages to the most sophisticated web apps.

Julian Simioni is a software developer from San Francisco now living in Berlin.
Outside of work Julian is a pilot, cyclist, and servant to two cats.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. 

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or an expert, a theorist or a practicing artist/technologist, we invite you to join us on Friday, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I'm not gonna lie: there might be code on the screen at some point, but we try to keep technical explanations reasonably short :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

... or read our hackpad to see what we usually talk about: http://tinyurl.com/ccstampad

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/
Please make sure you agree with its content.

ACCESSIBILITY
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. Creations can range from live visuals and custom VJing tools to visual art and generative design, art installations, net.art, interactive art, projection mapping, sound art and much more.

The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. 

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or a practicing artist/designer/technologist... we invite you to join us on Saturday and see for yourself.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I’m not gonna lie: many of us like to write code, but we try to keep our geeky side in check :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
During the jam, participants from various backgrounds are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation, so making mistakes is not only okay, it's actually encouraged!

We also often propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees.

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY 
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

<a href="https://github.com/SableRaf/CCBerlin/tree/master/SafeSpacePolicy"></a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
Enter the world of social coding with Git and GitHub! In this course we'll introduce you to GitHub, a free online service where over 2 million developers from around the world share their code. We'll show you how to share your code, meet like-minded programmers, and participate in other projects. You can even host simple websites using GitHub. Whether you just want to share a little script, connect with fellow programmers or contribute to some of the largest and most dynamic software projects in the world, we'll show you how to get started!

This course requires no previous knowledge of Git and is suitable for beginners of any programming language. No programming will be required during the course, but feel free to bring along your code for sharing on GitHub. You will need to bring your own laptop.
name: OTS workshop: Social Coding with GitHub

description:
Hackership n Tell! 

Demos from the current intake of Hackership

Hackership Batch-2 in Gran Canaria just finished and we would like to celebrate with you! Come and hear short presentations from some members of this intake, and ask learners and coaches any questions you might have about the initiative! During Hackership there are workshops, presentations and weekly demos very similar to this nights format. So come and hear what some current learners at Hackership have been upto the last 9 weeks, Or even better, present something yourself.

And, if you are interested in attending Hackership in Berlin this Summer or Costa Rica this September, it will also be your chance to speak to one of the volunteers and alumni from this initiative and learn more.  

Demo yourself too!

 Are you building something awesome right now that you want to share or need feedback on?  In the spirit of Hack n’Tell Berlin, we will have an open forum for short presentations of cool hacks and projects. We'll give you 5 minutes to show off your tool, hack, library (did you just write a library to access the Meetup API in Go!?), whatever. We're language and software/hardware agnostic, so it's all fair game.

After you present, it's an open forum. The audience will ask questions and provide feedback.

There is no limit to the kind of hacks that can be presented. Demo cool stuff, no matter if it's a mobile app, website, desktop program or library. Anything is allowed, just cross the line to awesomeness - and if it fails it should do it beautifully.

Here’s how it works:

• You'll get 5 minutes to present in English

• You or your team should have built it yourself

• People can ask you questions afterwards

• NO PURE SLIDEDECKS, no pitches, only demos + code

• Show us code!!! (reasonable exemptions may be possible)

• Entertain us!

• You only show us projects you developed. 

We hope you can make it and demo something you are working on. As ever, the focus is on sharing and learning, so don’t be shy!

Note, If you are thinking of demo-ing, please send a message via Meetup, just so we have an idea of numbers.

Peace, love and curiosity. <3

*Thanks to HacknTell Berlin for their great outline. The rules and structure of the night as described here are taken from their page.
name: Hackership nTell! Open Demo Night!

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): IT Security Talk

Ever wondered how the NSA could collect data? We'll discuss technical methods that can be used to collect data from IT systems, what's possible, what's not, and how we can keep our communications private. We'll do a live demonstration of a communications hack that could be used by attackers. We'll also discuss how online accounts can be stolen and how to stay safe.

Aleksandra Salvaterra is the former head of internal IT at SKY TV and an IT security expert with years of industry experience.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: IT Security Talk

description:
Background illustration by Abe Pazos (submit yours for #19!)

The Creative Code Stammtisch is a monthly open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. 

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or an expert, a theorist or a practicing artist/technologist, we invite you to join us on Friday, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I'm not gonna lie: there might be code on the screen at some point, but we try to keep technical explanations reasonably short :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

... or read our hackpad to see what we usually talk about: http://tinyurl.com/ccstampad

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/
Please make sure you agree with its content.

ACCESSIBILITY
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

Rachel Uwa
rachel@opentechschool.org
+49 151 7537 4602

If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I’m not gonna lie: many of us like to write code, but we try to keep our geeky side in check :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
During the jam, participants from various backgrounds are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation, so making mistakes is not only okay, it's actually encouraged!

We also often propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees.

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY 
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

<a href="https://github.com/SableRaf/CCBerlin/tree/master/SafeSpacePolicy"></a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.

description:
The next iteration of our get-together to learn more R (http://www.r-project.org/) and hack data using statistics is coming up this Thursday.

The co-learning group is going to be very informal and self-driven, so bring your own data, tutorials, projects etc. for an evening of shared learning and hacking! We will have opportunities during the evening to share what we learned, ask questions and share resources, however, this is not going to be a formal workshop where coaches guide the process.

If this sounds like your thing, sign up here and don't forget to bring your own laptop!! :-)

Some resources to get you started and inspired: https://github.com/ellenkoenig/R-co-learning-resources
name: "R & Statistical Data Analysis" Co-Learning

description:
SQL databases are one of the most commonly used form of data storage. From storing inventories of online shops to data from scientific research or financial markets, SQL databases allow for a structured representation of huge amounts of data. The SQL language is used to obtain the desired information from the data. For example, all shop items bought by a particular customer in the last two months. 

Who can participate in this event?

Anyone interested in using and understanding SQL. In particular for applications in business, finance, sociology, and other fields. No existing knowledge about databases or programming in general is required.

What should you bring?

A Computer. Windows, Mac, Linux are all fine. No need to install any software beforehand. The coaches will provide you with all necessary software as well as the sample data required for the tasks of the course.

If you want to help out as a coach rather than attend the workshop, please get in touch with me at bettina.shzu@gmail.com
name: Workshop 2: Using SQL to obtain information from databases

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/

IXDS is located on the street level. It's our first event there, so we still have to check the accessibility situation. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

IXDS
Paul-Linke-Ufer 39/40, Berlin
(third backyard, on the right side) 

CONTACT

Rachel Uwa
rachel@opentechschool.org
+49 151 7537 4602

Background illustration by Abe Pazos.

Do you want your work to be featured as the poster image for the next Stammtisch? Please send a 1200 by 1200 pixels image in JPG or PNG format at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.

On the 2th and 3th of May we are hosting the Young Science Hack Day. Children between 12 and 16 year can tinker and creative with hardware, datasets and play around with science.

For questions and registration contact:
ramin@opentechschool.org

The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. Creations can range from live visuals and custom VJing tools to visual art and generative design, art installations, net.art, interactive art, projection mapping, sound art and much more.

The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. 

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or a practicing artist/designer/technologist... we invite you to join us on Saturday and see for yourself.

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): From bits to unicode: how text is stored on a computer

Storing text on a digital device is not as easy as it seems at first glance. This talk will introduce you to modern and not so modern standards like ASCII, Windows-1252 and Unicode. You'll learn what differentiates a character set from a character encoding and how to handle text in your everyday programming.

Andreas Hug is technical lead at Moccu, a digital agency based in Berlin. Most of the time he uses Python and Django to build backend systems for websites and web applications. He also likes to tweak the agency's workflow with various tools and techniques. At OpenTechSchool Andreas is mainly engaged in the Python group where he organizes workshops and contributes to the learning materials.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

name: Learners Meetup: How is text really stored?

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is a monthly open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions.  

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or an expert, a theorist or a practising artist/technologist, we invite you to join us on Friday, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I'm not gonna lie: there might be code on the screen at some point, but we try to keep technical explanations reasonably short :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

... or read our hackpad to see what we usually talk about: http://tinyurl.com/ccstampad

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/
Please make sure you agree with its content.

ACCESSIBILITY
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT?
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

CONTACT
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602

- - -

Background illustration by Raphaël de Courville.

Do you want your work to be featured as the poster image for the next Stammtisch? Please send a 500 by 500 pixels image in JPG or PNG format at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.
how_to_find_us: Enter through one of the two gates, then walk to the back of the compound. Spot the door across from the white mailboxes and ring at "co-up".
name: Creative Code Stammtisch #20

description:
If doors are locked call Bastian: +491636035693

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. Afterwards, we’ll end the day with celebratory drinks and socializing at co.up! 

Drinks can be purchased for cheap at the venue. As for food, we’ll have a lunch break and there are plenty of restaurants around the venue. Also, feel free to bring you own drinks and food!

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the crazy experiments on Codepen.io or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching workshops and organizing events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website:  http://cssclasses.cssconf.eu/
name: CSSclasses

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is all about building things in the browser: HTML, CSS and lots of JavaScript.

We are a friendly group that meets every Wednesday (except when the Learners Meetup takes place which is usually the first of the month) to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or is happy to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials. We're here to help with that, too. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

• JavaScript for Beginners 1
 • JavaScript for Beginners 2
 • Intro to HTML/CSS

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. Creations can range from live visuals and custom VJing tools to visual art and generative design, art installations, net.art, interactive art, projection mapping, sound art and much more.

The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. 

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or a practicing artist/designer/technologist... we invite you to join us on Saturday and see for yourself.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I’m not gonna lie: many of us like to write code, but we try to keep our geeky side in check :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
During the jam, participants from various backgrounds are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation, so making mistakes is not only okay, it's actually encouraged!

We also often propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees.

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY 
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

<a href="https://github.com/SableRaf/CCBerlin/tree/master/SafeSpacePolicy"></a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): Install all the things! What are package management systems and what are they good for? 

Installing software is easy. Just tell your app-store or package management system what you want and it will download, install and update the software for you. But it has not always been like that and sometimes it can be confusing. In this talk you will learn how package management systems work, how they became a thing, what this had to do with Free/Libre Open Source Software and how to use one on Debian or Ubuntu Linux.

Nicolai von Neudeck works as a system administrator at the Humboldt-University where he also studies Cultural Anthropology. He likes franco-belgian comics, cyborgs and repairing things. At OpenTechSchool he helps run the Learners Meetup and has coached at an "Opening Hardware" workshop.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 60 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. Creations can range from live visuals and custom VJing tools to visual art and generative design, art installations, net.art, interactive art, projection mapping, sound art and much more.

The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. 

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or a practicing artist/designer/technologist... we invite you to join us on Saturday and see for yourself.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I’m not gonna lie: many of us like to write code, but we try to keep our geeky side in check :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
During the jam, participants from various backgrounds are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation, so making mistakes is not only okay, it's actually encouraged!

We also often propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees.

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY 
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

<a href="https://github.com/SableRaf/CCBerlin/tree/master/SafeSpacePolicy"></a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
A tutorial for complete newbies, to help you get your feet wet in programming.
We'll learn the basic concepts which apply to virtually all programming languages using Python.
name: Programming for Beginners

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is all about building things in the browser: HTML, CSS and lots of JavaScript.

We are a friendly group that meets every Wednesday (except when the Learners Meetup takes place which is usually the first of the month) to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or is happy to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials. We're here to help with that, too. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

• JavaScript for Beginners 1
 • JavaScript for Beginners 2
 • Intro to HTML/CSS

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)
how_to_find_us: 5th floor - If the gate is close try the small one. Get inside of the backyard and than turn left (block in the middle)

description:

You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.

name: Web Frontend Co-Learning

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): Spy on your programs with strace! 

Strace is a funky utility that lets you see what any program is doing, no matter what language it was written in. Julia Evans wrote an awesome zine which explains how it works and how to use it. Let's go through the zine and experiment together! We will go under the hood of programs and understand what system calls are.

Duana Stanley works as a generalist polyglot software engineer at SoundCloud. She's currently learning Android and Arduino (everything starting with A!) and she believes everyone is technical, they just have different interests and hobbies.

Discussion (ca. 15 mins): Creating the Learners Manifesto

It's really important to OpenTechSchool that we have an environment where learners can flourish and explore. But learning can be hard, and coaching also. Bettina Shzu is putting together a "Learners Manifesto" that sets guidelines for effective learning and coaching, and we need your input! 

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: Spy on your programs with strace!

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. Creations can range from live visuals and custom VJing tools to visual art and generative design, art installations, net.art, interactive art, projection mapping, sound art and much more.

The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. 

Wether you consider yourself to be a beginner or a practicing artist/designer/technologist... we invite you to join us on Saturday and see for yourself.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I’m not gonna lie: many of us like to write code, but we try to keep our geeky side in check :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
During the jam, participants from various backgrounds are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation, so making mistakes is not only okay, it's actually encouraged!

We also often propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees.

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY 
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to female artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

<a href="https://github.com/SableRaf/CCBerlin/tree/master/SafeSpacePolicy"></a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 1.50€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
Are you interested in coaching? Just RSVP and let us know in the comments! 

--- 

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. Afterwards, we’ll end the day with celebratory drinks and socializing at co.up! 

Drinks can be purchased for cheap at the venue. As for food, we’ll have a lunch break and there are plenty of restaurants around the venue. Also, feel free to bring you own drinks and food!

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the crazy experiments on Codepen.io or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching workshops and organizing events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website:  http://cssclasses.cssconf.eu/

***

Join our Slack channel!

https://cssclasses.herokuapp.com/

***

Are you interested in coaching? Just RSVP and let us know in the comments! 

***

If on the day of the event the doors are locked, call Bastian: +491636035693
name: CSSclasses

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).

description:
Always wanted to contribute to an open source project, but not sure where to start? Join us for the very first OpenSourceBash!

Together with Hackership and Women Who Code we organize OpenSourceBash, an event that gives open source projects a chance to present their work and find new contributors. We will have 15 projects presenting, including Diaspora, VLC, the Rust language and Hoodie. You can find all the details and a full agenda here!

IMPORTANT: To secure your spot for this event, you need to sign up through the OpenSourceBash website.

We have regular tickets, for which we ask you to make an (optional) donation to OpenTechSchool - you decide how much you want to donate. Once we run out of normal tickets, we'll still have additional tickets available for marginalized groups (if that sounds strange, here's our reasoning).

Or, if you contribute to an open source project and would like to present: This is your chance, just hit apply!

See you there,

– Bashy, the GNUnicorn

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is a monthly open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. 

Whether you consider yourself to be a beginner or an expert, a theorist or a practicing artist/technologist, we invite you to join us on Friday, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on.

If you're just getting started, the following video gives a rather comprehensive overview of what creative coding can look like: http://video.pbs.org/video/2322911761/ 

Note that you don't need to be a coder yourself! We are all about the intersection of disciplines so let us repeat this: this event is NOT just for coders! If you dig media art, you will enjoy yourself, and maybe even learn something! I'm not gonna lie: there might be code on the screen at some point, but we try to keep technical explanations reasonably short :)

Shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

... or read our hackpad to see what we usually talk about: http://tinyurl.com/ccstampad

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
As members of Open Tech School and as individuals, our team is committed to embracing diversity. We want everyone to feel welcome and supported. This is why we are specifically reaching out to women artists, designers, theorists, students and learners. We want you to know that this community belongs to YOU. We wish for a diversity of opinions to be represented and we will go out of our way to make the largest possible range of voices heard. This invitation extends, of course, to everyone who feels underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
Our events are free and open to everyone, regardless of their gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, age, social situation and religion (or lack thereof). We are dedicated to providing a harassment-free creative space where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves. We expect you to respect and contribute to this environment.

We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/
Please make sure you agree with its content.

ACCESSIBILITY
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

WHERE IS IT?
CO.UP coworking space.
Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

CONTACT
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602

- - -

Flyer illustration by Abe Pazos.

Do you want your work to be featured on the flyer of the next Stammtisch? Please send a image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com. Square format — at least 500 by 500 pixels — JPG or PNG.
how_to_find_us: Walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, find the door across from white mailboxes. Ring at Co.Up.

description:
Learn to code, no matter how old you are: Join OpenTechSchool and Coder Dojo Potsdam at the Maker Faire Berlin. We coach in Python, Javascript, Arduino and more.

You MUST get a ticket for the Maker Faire, using the code FLDUXH it is free. However the 0€ only show up at the end. You can go to the Maker Faire from 10:00 to 18:00 with this ticket.

You should bring your own Laptop/Smartphone/Tablet. We only have a few there. If you like to coach, leave a note.

• meshcon, the host

We are a friendly group that meets every Wednesday (except when the Learners Meetup takes place which is usually the first of the month) to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or is happy to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials. We're here to help with that, too. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

• JavaScript for Beginners 1
 • JavaScript for Beginners 2
 • Intro to HTML/CSS

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)
how_to_find_us: 5th floor - If the gate is close try the small one. Get inside of the backyard and than turn left (block in the middle)
name: Web Frontend Co-Learning

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We are in the 3rd or 5th floor, please check the signs
name: Python Co-Learning

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): Intro to A/B Testing: Experimenting with product ideas the „Mad Scientist" way

Most major online platforms these days run A/B tests. A lot of them. From entire features to the wording in e-mails, almost everything gets A/B tested.

The idea is simple: If you have a large enough user base, you can roll out two or more different versions of your feature, design or wording to different parts of your user base, and see which one is more successful. This is called „experimentation“ on your user base, the same way pharmaceutical companies run trials of medicine before they sell them to the whole population.

The proper implementation of an online A/B test is kind of tricky, however. This talk introduces the coding, process and statistical aspects of how to create A/B tests for your own features (or e-mail wording!).

Ellen is a data applications engineer @ SoundCloud and aspiring social psychologist. She is is deeply fascinated by all sorts of data and code related topics such as data analysis, data hacking, code quality, tech culture and the implications of information technology for our future daily lives. She also enjoys sharing her favorite interests with others, by speaking at conferences and meetups, organizing meetups for OpenTechSchool and coaching in workshops.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: A/B Testing - Experiment like a Mad Scientist!

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is usually a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. Great conversations happen at the intersection of cultures, from a collision of perspectives. Please help us help YOU attend a better meetup! 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor. We will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @P5Jam

WHERE IS IT? 
CO.UP coworking space. 
Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes)

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Abe Pazos.

Do you want your work to be featured for the next Stammtisch? Please send a image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com. Square format — at least 500 by 500 pixels — JPG or PNG. Include the name or pseudonym you want us to use and a link to your website (if you want).
how_to_find_us: Walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, find the door across from white mailboxes. Ring at Co.Up third floor.

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): Finding user needs by listening and asking

Most of you will know testing a website or service with users. Doing this helps to find out if the product is *usable*. But how do you determine what could be *useful*? Jan will introduce you to listening to your user and asking questions
which lead to interesting and inspiring answers.

Jan is a user researcher and educator working at USEEDS°. He is interested in ways to make research and design work smoothly together to create useful products.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

- Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org

description:
Directions for the entrance

Wimdu's office is located on the 4th floor.

Are you interested in coaching? Just RSVP and let us know in the comments! 

--- 

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. 

Some drinks and food will be provided by Wimdu :)

Agenda for Saturday:

09:30-10:00 Install Party (optional)

10:00-10:15 Welcome

10:15-12:00 Coding in groups

12:30-13:30 Lunch

13:30-17:00 Coding in groups

17:00-17:45 Demos

17:45-18:00 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website:  http://cssclasses.cssconf.eu/

***

Join our Slack channel!

https://cssclasses.herokuapp.com/

***

Are you interested in coaching? Just RSVP and let us know in the comments! 

***

description:

We are a friendly group that meets every Wednesday (except when the Learners Meetup takes place which is usually the first of the month) to learn together and work on our projects. description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the initiative to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor. We will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org

CO.UP coworking space. 
Adalbertstr. 7-8

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:

You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla. Go to http://rust-lang.org/ for details.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group! Remember to bring your laptop!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://github.com/brson/multirust/ (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

   - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

   - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): "Intro to orchestration: Reproduceable and self-documenting computer configuration."

Configuring computers properly is a lot of work. Doing it on several machines is even more tedious. And remembering what exactly one did five weeks later is next to impossible. And of course one tends to not document properly what one did because doing it was already more than enough labour. Do not even mention sharing the configuring you did with others.
Orchestration promises to change all that for the better and it mostly does. The talk will quickly show why orchestration is a thing, what it promises and what it actually does. There will be a small live-demo with an easy to use orchestration tool called Ansible.

Nicolai is a cultural anthropologist who works in a small start up where he mostly configures computers. He likes franco-belgian comic-books and is interested in way too many things, among them cultural and material implications of tech.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: Intro to orchestration (what Devops do!)

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>
