Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

name: Python Co-Learning

description:
NodeSchool is a monthly code learning event co-hosted by NodeSchool.io and OpenTechSchool. We are a welcoming community in which people can learn Frontend technologies. Even though Node.js is the primary topic that participants learn, there is a broad set of interactive command-line lessons (called "workshoppers") which attendees can work on independently with the support of mentors and peers. Topics include introduction to JavaScript, Git, Patternlab, and React, among others. Workshoppers are available for every skill level—from absolute beginner to professional developer.

*** T I C K E T S ***
Attendance is free, but spots are limited. Tickets are available 1 week before the event. The URL to get them will be posted here (https://ti.to/nodeschool-berlin/17) and on our website (http://nodeschool.io/berlin/). Please make sure you only get a ticket if you know you can come! -> Food and soft drinks sponsored by Project A

Bring your laptop! And if you have any questions, feel free to message us by opening an issue on GitHub (https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin).

See you soon!
name: Node.js Co-Learning (NodeSchool)

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla. Go to http://rust-lang.org/ for details.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group! Remember to bring your laptop!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://github.com/brson/multirust/ (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:

We are a friendly group that meets almost every Wednesday to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop and your challenges and questions. how_to_find_us: 5th floor - If the gate is close try the small one. Get inside of the backyard and than turn left (block in the middle)
name: Web Frontend Co-Learning

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins): Intro to Statistics for Data Science

Data analysis has been essential for science for many decades, but today it affects design, business and policy making more than ever before and with big data it even got an all-over-the-place buzzword. So it is a good time to dive into data analysis!

The time frame is short and our lab is still figuring out how to teach you everything in 5 seconds via WiFi based thought transfer. Since they will not be finished until April, we will have a talk with some demos instead. You get to know essential ideas, caveats and tools for beginning with learning data analysis.

Jan is a user researcher and educator working at USEEDS°. He is
interested in ways to make research and design work smoothly together to
create useful products.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: Intro to Statistics for Data Science!

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

🚀 Exceptionally, we will be hosted at ART+COM Explore, an R&D space hosted by the Collegium Hungaricum Berlin (CHB) in Mitte. 🚀

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the initiative to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Yes! ART+COM Explore is on the ground floor and there are no steps.

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 29120374

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
ART+COM Explore
@ Collegium Hungaricum Berlin  
Dorotheenstraße 12   
(Enter through the metal gate. Walk straight to the back of the yard)

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Abe Pazos.

Do you want your work to be featured on the cover of the next Stammtisch? Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com. Square format — at least 500 by 500 pixels — JPG or PNG. Include the name or pseudonym you want us to use and a link to your website (if you want).
how_to_find_us: Enter through the metal gate and walk straight to the back of the yard. If the gate is closed, call 017629120374 or wave at us :-)

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!


Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://github.com/brson/multirust/ (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) Intro to Recommendations using Collaborative Filtering

Today the internet gives us almost unlimited access to movies, tv shows, music or items we could buy. Recommender Systems try to help us find things we might be interested in. Collaborative Filtering as a technique for Recommendation Systems is used by a variety of companies such as Netflix, Amazon or Spotify. This talk will cover its concepts on a high level.

by Laurence Bortfeld Right now I'm working as a Frontend Developer using React and React Native. Sometimes you can find me in the backend building APIs recently with GraphQL. If I'm not in front of a computer I enjoy cooking, kiteboarding or riding my bicycle through the city

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Email us at team.beginners-meetup@opentechschool.org
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: Intro to Recommendations using Collaborative Filtering!

description:
This is all about building things in the browser: HTML, CSS and lots of JavaScript.

We are a friendly group that meets almost every Wednesday to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or would love to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an experienced expert, we want to learn from each other.

Doors open latest at 19:30h, introduction round at 20:00h.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

description:
*** R S V P *** 
Attendance is free, but spots are limited. Go here to reserve a spot: https://ti.to/nodeschool-berlin/19 Please make sure you only get a ticket if you know you can come! 

NodeSchool is a monthly code learning event co-hosted by NodeSchool.io and OpenTechSchool. We are a welcoming community in which people can learn Node.js and JavaScript, as well as other web-related technologies. Even though Node.js is the primary topic that participants learn, there is a broad set of interactive command-line lessons (called "workshoppers") which attendees can work on independently with the support of mentors and peers. Topics include introduction to JavaScript, Git, Patternlab, and React, among others. Workshoppers are available for every skill level—from absolute beginner to professional developer.

-> Snacks and soft drinks sponsored by Project A

Bring your laptop! And if you have any questions, feel free to message us by opening an issue on GitHub (https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin).

See you soon!

description:
Are you interested in coaching? Just RSVP and let us know in the comments! 

--- 

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. 

Agenda for Saturday:

09:30-10:00 Install Party (optional)

10:00-10:15 Welcome

10:15-12:00 Coding in groups

12:30-13:30 Lunch

13:30-16:00 Coding in groups

16:00-16:30 Demos

16:30-16:45 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website: http://cssclass.es

***

Flexbox materials:

https://github.com/CSSclasses/_course-flexbox

***

Join our Slack channel!

https://cssclasses.herokuapp.com/

***

Are you interested in coaching? Just RSVP and let us know in the comments! 

***
name: CSSclasses

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

Talk (ca. 20 mins) What is it like to be a digital nomad?

You may have heard of a growing trend of people travelling for long periods while working as developers, designers or other type of knowledge workers. Is it as fun as it sounds? How do you pull it off? What are the pros and cons?

by Haiko Schol - Haiko is a freelance programmer who spent about eight months in 2015 travelling in Europe, the US and Asia. In this talk he will ll share his experiences with the Digital Nomad lifestyle.

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

🚀 Important note: This time again, we will be hosted at ART+COM Explore, an R&D space hosted by the Collegium Hungaricum Berlin (CHB) in Mitte. 🚀

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the initiative to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Yes! ART+COM Explore is on the ground floor and there are no steps.

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 29120374

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
ART+COM Explore
@ Collegium Hungaricum Berlin  
Dorotheenstraße 12   
(Enter through the metal gate. Walk straight to the back of the yard)

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Raphaël de Courville.

Do you want your work to be featured on the cover of the next Stammtisch? Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com. Square format — at least 500 by 500 pixels — JPG or PNG. Include the name or pseudonym you want us to use and a link to your website (if you want).
how_to_find_us: Enter through the metal gate and walk straight to the back of the yard. If the gate is closed, call 017629120374 or wave at us :-)
name: Creative Code Stammtisch #31 at CHB

description:
IMPORTANT: If you want to attend this event, you must register using the ti.to link. Meetup.com RSVPs will not be accepted.

https://ti.to/nodeschool-berlin/2016

Are you interested to learn JavaScript or Node ? On this full-day workshop event, you'll be able to spend time learning the basics of both of it - or even dive into more advanced topics. There are workshops available for every skill level -- from JS beginners all the way to experienced node programmers. Find peers at this event and with the help of mentors you'll be learning in an interactive, self-guided format.

NodeSchool is a community driven, open source educational platform that teaches various Node, JavaScript and other related skills.

We strive to be a welcoming and safe event for all attendees. Attendees have to follow the Code of Conduct.

You only need to bring your laptop.

👾 Special Announcement 👾

Did you hear about the Internet of Things and are interested to try it yourself? We'll have some Tessel 2 devices at the event. You can use it for example to run your own webpage that controls some LED lights. You'll only need to learn the basics of JavaScript and Node to get started with them (which of course you can do at this day as well).
Schedule

11:00 - 11.30 Introduction / Installation
11.30 - 13.00 Learning
13:00 - 14:00 Lunch Time
14:00 - 16:00 Learning
16:00 - 16:30 Coffee Break
16:30 - 19:00 Learning

See you there!
name: NodeSchool Berlin - International Day 2016

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.

name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) A simple intro to machine learning for the curious but scared

Machine learning is a hot topic right now, that many people (including myself) get excited about. It is also notoriously confusing to get into unless you got started on this in uni already. There seems to be this impenetrable forrest of statistics-heavy textbooks, obscure mathematical optimization techniques and fancy buzzwords that I personally cannot even get really fascinated with, let alone digest in my spare time.
Despite my background in computer science, it took me many false starts to get even a bit of a hold of this topic. In my talk I want to summarize the very basic ideas that often get left out of other „Introductions“ to the topic that I wish someone had told me a few years ago. I will cover what it actually means when a machine „learns“, a high level overview of „how“ machines can learn, and some pointers to friendly resources that can get you started. 

by Ellen König - Ellen works as an „A/B testing" engineer at SoundCloud, somewhere on the intersection of programming and applied statistics. She has an academic background in Computer Science, and a largely self-taught background in stats and ML. She also loves to learn to dance and all sorts of other organized and self-taught learning opportunities on a wide range of topics.  

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on  http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: A simple intro to machine learning for the curious but scared

description:
This is all about building things in the browser: HTML, CSS and lots of JavaScript.

We are a friendly group that meets almost every Wednesday to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or would love to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an experienced expert, we want to learn from each other.

Doors open latest at 19:30h, introduction round at 20:00h.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials. We're here to help with that, too. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

JavaScript for Beginners 1 | JavaScript for Beginners 2 | Intro to HTML/CSS

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)

You're also welcome to join our chat on Gitter.
how_to_find_us: 5th floor - If the gate is close try the small one. Get inside of the backyard and than turn left (block in the middle)
name: Web Frontend Co-Learning

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

🚀 Important note: This time again, we will be hosted at ART+COM Explore, an R&D space hosted by the Collegium Hungaricum Berlin (CHB) in Mitte. 🚀

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the initiative to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Yes! ART+COM Explore is on the ground floor and there are no steps.

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 29120374

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
ART+COM Explore
@ Collegium Hungaricum Berlin  
Dorotheenstraße 12   
(Enter through the metal gate. Walk straight to the back of the yard)

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Abe Pazos.

Do you want your work to be featured on the cover of the next Stammtisch? Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.
how_to_find_us: Enter through the metal gate and walk straight to the back of the yard. If the gate is closed, call 017629120374 or wave at us :-)
name: Creative Code Stammtisch #32 at CHB

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

name: Python Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://github.com/brson/multirust/ (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy

description:
IMPORTANT: If you want to attend this event, you must register using the ti.to link. Meetup.com RSVPs will not be accepted.

NodeSchool is a monthly code learning event co-hosted by NodeSchool.io and OpenTechSchool. We are a welcoming community in which people can learn Node.js and JavaScript, as well as other web-related technologies. Even though Node.js is the primary topic that participants learn, there is a broad set of interactive command-line lessons (called "workshoppers") which attendees can work on independently with the support of mentors and peers. Topics include introduction to JavaScript, Git, Patternlab, and React, among others. Workshoppers are available for every skill level—from absolute beginner to professional developer.

*** R S V P *** 
Attendance is free, but spots are limited. Go here to reserve a spot: https://ti.to/nodeschool-berlin (they become available a few days before the event). Please make sure you only get a ticket if you know you can come! 

-> Snacks and soft drinks sponsored by Project A

Bring your laptop! And if you have any questions, feel free to message us by opening an issue on GitHub (https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin).

See you soon!
name: Node.js Co-Learning (NodeSchool)

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) Contributing to Open Source Software

A lot of the software we use is "Open Source software" - this means it is collaboratively created by people on the Internet. It's really rewarding to take part in that, and in the talk you can get tips on how to get started. Contributing to Open Source can be a little daunting, so the talk also comes with tips on how to contribute in such a way that your contribution gets accepted.

by Martin Meyerhoff - Martin is a political scientist turned web developer. With his colleagues at the web consultancy bitspire, he build websites for other people.
He's also a co-maintainer of the open source Content Management System AlchemyCMS, and of the open source e-commerce framework Solidus. Both of these are tools he needs for his daily work.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on  http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: Contributing to Open Source

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the initiative to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 29120374

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Soma Holiday.

Do you want your work to be featured on the cover of the next Stammtisch? Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.
how_to_find_us: Enter through one of the two gates, then walk to the back of the compound. Spot the door across from the white mailboxes and ring at "co-up".

name: Python Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://github.com/brson/multirust/ (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
IMPORTANT: If you want to attend this event, you must register at https://ti.to/nodeschool-berlin/22. Meetup.com RSVPs will not be accepted.

NodeSchool is a monthly code learning event co-hosted by NodeSchool.io and OpenTechSchool. We are a welcoming community in which people can learn Node.js and JavaScript, as well as other web-related technologies. Even though Node.js is the primary topic that participants learn, there is a broad set of interactive command-line lessons (called "workshoppers") which attendees can work on independently with the support of mentors and peers. Topics include introduction to JavaScript, Git, Patternlab, and React, among others. Workshoppers are available for every skill level—from absolute beginner to professional developer.

*** R S V P *** 
Attendance is free, but spots are limited. Go here to reserve a spot: https://ti.to/nodeschool-berlin/22. Please make sure you only get a ticket if you know you can come! 

-> Snacks and soft drinks sponsored by Project A

Bring your laptop! And if you have any questions, feel free to message us by opening an issue on GitHub (https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin).

See you soon!
name: Node.js Co-Learning (NodeSchool)

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up

name: Web Frontend Co-Learning

description:
We are very happy to announce the organisation of the very first RustBridge here in Berlin: a hands-on workshop to learn Rust. As part of RustFest taking place that weekend, the OpenTechSchool Berlin is organising a beta-run of a beginners workshop to learn Rust on Sunday, September 18th, 2016 at Co-Up.

What is Rust ?

Rust is a new, safe systems programming language developed primarily by Mozilla. Systems programming? You might have heard of C/C++ as languages to built low-level and super fast programs with. Rust plays in the same league but as a very young language is from the ground up designed to deal with concurrent multi-processing environments (like multi-core CPUs). Further more it provides new mechanism to improve "safety" of your programs memory, the primary reason why C/C++ are considered hard and that high level languages like Python, Ruby and Javascript handle for you with a high performance penalty.

Or to say it with the claim from rust-lang.org: "Rust is a systems programming language that runs blazingly fast, prevents segfaults, and guarantees thread safety."

What is RustBridge?

In the traditions of RailsBridge, RustBridge is a community initiative to develop a workshop to teach absolute beginners about programming using Rust. This will be its very first trial workshop. Therefore the material might be a little rough and not super polished yet: feedback is very welcome!

We are currently aiming for two distinct workshops to work through on your own. While one aims to be suitable for beginners the other is already a bit more challenging and will bring you deeper into more advanced rust topics. Though the format eventually aims to be suitable for total beginners, for this edition we require that you have some essential programming experience. It's still a beta!

This event is organised in collaboration and as part of RustFest – a  community conference dedicated to the Rust Programming language taking place on the very same weekend of September 17th/18th. You can learn more (and get ticket) at RustFest.EU.

All Requirements, details and sign up over on the community forum.
name: RustBridge Workshop – Learn Rust at RustFest

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
***
Learning Materials: cssclass.es/materials 
Slack channel: cssclasses.herokuapp.com

***

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 5-6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. 

Agenda for Sunday: 

10:30 Doors open

11:00-11:15 Welcome

11:15-13:00 Coding in groups

13:00-14:00 Lunch Break (there are many food options in the area, or you can bring your own)

14:00-16:30 Coding in groups

16:30-17:00 Demos

17:00-17:30 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website: http://cssclass.es

***

Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we'll contact you.

***

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)

You're also welcome to join our chat on Gitter.

We do have a code of conduct.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up

description:
IMPORTANT: If you want to attend this event, you must register at https://ti.to/nodeschool-berlin/23. Meetup.com RSVPs will not be accepted.

NodeSchool is a monthly code learning event co-hosted by NodeSchool.io and OpenTechSchool. We are a welcoming community in which people can learn Node.js and JavaScript, as well as other web-related technologies. Even though Node.js is the primary topic that participants learn, there is a broad set of interactive command-line lessons (called "workshoppers") which attendees can work on independently with the support of mentors and peers. Topics include introduction to JavaScript, Git, Patternlab, and React, among others. Workshoppers are available for every skill level—from absolute beginner to professional developer.

-> Snacks and soft drinks sponsored by Project A

Bring your laptop! And if you have any questions, feel free to message us by opening an issue on GitHub (https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin).

See you soon!

There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the initiative to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 29120374

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Abe Pazos.

Do you want your work to be featured on the cover of the next Stammtisch? Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.
how_to_find_us: Enter through one of the two gates, then walk to the back of the compound. Spot the door across from the white mailboxes and ring at "co-up".
name: Creative Code Stammtisch #36 at CO.UP

description:
***
Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we’ll contact you. 

***

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 5-6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. 

Agenda for Sunday: 

10:30 Doors open

11:00-11:15 Welcome

11:15-13:00 Coding in groups

13:00-14:00 Lunch Break (there are many food options in the area, or you can bring your own)

14:00-16:30 Coding in groups

16:30-17:00 Demos

17:00-17:30 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website: http://cssclass.es

Learning Materials: cssclass.es/materials 
Slack channel: slack.cssclass.es

***

Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we'll contact you.

***
name: CSSclasses

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.

name: Go Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs/ (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :)

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

description:
Join us for an workshop to prepare the Website Relauch Hack-Day.

The goal of this day is to set the foundation for a successful website relaunch. In particular we want to achieve the following aspects, which can be done simultaneously:

• ⬜️ Upgrade Website to latest Jekyll, create setup guide

• ⬜️ Research and decide on a CSS foundation (e.g. grid), UI-Toolkit, colors and language

• ⬜️ Content Structure and "Sitemap"

• ⬜️ Put open tasks into clear and achievable Github tickets

At the end of the event, we'd like have a good foundation that also people not intimately familiar with our setup can contribute. Secondly we want to have everything in place to run the Website Relaunch Hack-Day with it, preferably by having defined people leading specific aspects during the event.
name: Prepping the Website Relaunch

Ben and two Martins are hanging out at Betahaus Café if you want to join.

We will provide coffee and hot water for tea, if you like. Please feel welcome to bring cookies and such to share!

About:

This is an open Co-Learning day where you can just come by and work on your project if you have questions to a specific topic or just feel stuck you can ask us to help we have a few coaches around that can assist you if needed.

If you do not have a laptop but still want to come by we have a few spare Laptops to work with. Please let us know in the comments below!

There will be coaches for Go, Rust, Python and Web Technologies (JavaScript, HTML and CSS), so if you need help with your project it is the perfect place to get help. But if you want help with anything else, or want to coach, please come by, too!

Or if you want to get started with programming, we have great learning materials ready for you at learn.opentechschool.org.

Location

description:
The Go Co-Learning group is a biweekly meetup for everyone interested in learning Go/Golang.

We have no fixed agenda and there are no talks or lectures. Instead we work on tutorials or projects and help each other when we get stuck. We meet on every (well most) first and third Tuesday of the month.

Make sure to bring a laptop! If you don't have access to one, message one of the organisers a few days in advance. We can probably bring one from the OpenTechSchool stash. :)
name: Go Co-Learning

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) TRANSISTOR ZERO: Reconstructing the brain of a computer

The programming environments that we use these days are high-level, with functional programming, object orientation, traits, and more. But all this abstraction has made us forget what the core of a computer really is. What are registers? Latches? Stacks? Frame pointers? Conditional jumps? Computers can seem quirky at times, and occasionally even resemble black magic. Dive into the core of a computer, however, and the high-level puzzle pieces can finally click together. This talk will show how you could build a simple computer from scratch, and explain all core concepts along the way.

by Denis Defreyne - Denis Defreyne is a software engineer at SoundCloud, where he has built large parts of the On SoundCloud monetisation programme, and is now member of the core engineering team. In his spare time, he often indulges in his obsession for electronic music, plays around with exciting new technologies, and chases cats.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on  http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: The place is a bit hard to find. Go through the big metal gate to the left of Adalbertstr. 7, straight to the far end of the courtyard, and in the first tunnel to your right. Ring the doorbell with "co.up". It's on 3rd floor.
name: Learners Meetup: TRANSISTOR ZERO - Reconstructing the brain of a computer

description:
Do you want to learn to...

• use git and github

• work collaboratively in a team

• build websites with jekyll

• host websites on github-pages

• use CSS to implement your design ideas

•  contribute to a real project

Join us for the🎉OpenTechSchool-Website Relaunch Hack-Day🎉!

We will start the day with a short overview of the technologies used, how they tie together and the tasks we are trying to achieve in this day. Then we will break out into smaller teams depending on the aspects you'd like to focus on. Every group decides which tasks it wants to work on depending on skill and interest and how long they think it would take them to achieve those. We will give introductions on how to use the tools in question for those unfamiliar with them and then teams go about to try to finish their tasks.

At the end all teams quickly present what they've done during the day and what their thought process was behind them.

If you are interested in contributing to or just learning about how to define the foundations and tasks, please join us for the preparation meeting on November 26th, too!
name: 🎉 Website Relaunch Hack-Day 🎉

There's always someone around that is happy to help you or would love to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an experienced expert, we want to learn from each other.

Doors open latest at 19:30h, introduction round at 20:00h.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials. We're here to help with that, too. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

JavaScript for Beginners 1 | JavaScript for Beginners 2 | Intro to HTML/CSS

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)

You're also welcome to join our chat on Gitter.

We do have a code of conduct.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
