description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
We do our best to create a welcoming environment for people of all genders, and this takes more than just words. Please help us keep our community diverse by thinking of a female friend who could enjoy this meetup, and inviting them to join... seriously, just stop reading and do it 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 70070572 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Mocomatics.

We'd love to feature your work on the cover for the next Stammtisch! Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.
how_to_find_us: Enter through one of the two gates, then walk to the back of the compound. Spot the door across from the white mailboxes and ring at "co-up".
name: Creative Code Stammtisch #38 at CO.UP

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We are in the 3rd or 5th floor, please check the signs
name: Python Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
We do our best to create a welcoming environment for people of all genders, and this takes more than just words. Please help us keep our community diverse by thinking of a female friend who could enjoy this meetup, and inviting them to join... seriously, just stop reading and do it 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 70070572 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Mei-Fang Liau & Abe Pazos.

We'd love to feature your work on the cover for the next Stammtisch! Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.
how_to_find_us: Enter through one of the two gates, then walk to the back of the compound. Spot the door across from the white mailboxes and ring at "co-up".
name: Creative Code Stammtisch #39 at CO.UP

description:
***
Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we’ll contact you. 

***

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 5-6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. 

Agenda for Sunday: 

10:30 Doors open

11:00-11:15 Welcome

11:15-13:00 Coding in groups

13:00-14:00 Lunch Break (there are many food options in the area, or you can bring your own)

14:00-16:30 Coding in groups

16:30-17:00 Demos

17:00-17:30 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website: http://cssclass.es

Learning Materials: cssclass.es/materials 
Slack channel: slack.cssclass.es

***

Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we'll contact you.

***

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

description:
English version below

Achtung: Bitte bewirb dich hier für die Teilnahme: https://goo.gl/forms/61TzA8u2MvAWYPHo1. Das RSVP auf meetup.com ist keine Garantie für einen Platz!

Dieser kostenlose und von Freiwilligen organisierte Workshop der OpenTechSchool richtet sich an alle die Programmieren lernen wollen oder es einfach einmal ausprobieren möchten. Es sind keine Vorkenntnisse nötig!

Hast du schon etwas Erfahrung, melde dich als Coach! 

Mit unserem Tutorial wirst du die Grundlagen der Programmierung kreativ und interaktiv erlernen. Dabei stehen dir Coaches zur Seite, die dir helfen und die du auch alles mögliche fragen kannst.

Der Veranstaltungsort ist ein Begegnungsort und Kulturzentrum für Menschen mit und ohne Fluchthintergrund. Wir bieten diesen Workshop ganz besonders auch Geflüchteten und Aktiven dieser Initiative an und haben für sie einen Teil der Plätze reserviert.

Es gilt unser Verhaltenskodex (Code of Conduct).

Please apply here to participate: https://goo.gl/forms/61TzA8u2MvAWYPHo1. The RSVP here on Meetup.com does not guarantee you a space!

This OpenTechSchool workshop is for everyone that wants to learn programming or just try it out. No previous experience required at all! It is free and organized only by volunteers.

If you already have some programming experience, please sign up as a coach!

Using our tutorial you will learn the basics of programming in a creative and interactive way. There will be coaches around to support you and ready to answer any kind of questions.

The location is a cultural center for refugees and other locals in Moabit. A part of the seats for this workshop will be reserved for members of this community.

Our Code of Conduct applies.

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome!

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
We do our best to create a welcoming environment for people of all genders, and this takes more than just words. Please help us keep our community diverse by thinking of a female friend who could enjoy this meetup, and inviting them to join... seriously, just stop reading and do it 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 70070572 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Sabine Wolf (Based on the work of Hamid Naderi Yeganeh).

We'd love to feature your work on the cover for the next Stammtisch! Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.

description:

We have no fixed agenda and there are no talks or lectures. Instead we work on tutorials or projects and help each other when we get stuck. We meet on every (well most) first and third Tuesday of the month.

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
how_to_find_us: 5th floor, together with the Python Co-Learning

description:
Learners' Meetup: The 7 wonders of Agile development

CHANGE OF VENUE! For this meetup we will be at bitcrowd, not Co-up

A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) 7 wonders of agile development

We all love Pair programming, Visualization, Participation, Cross-functionality, Prioritization, Transparency, but sometimes it´s hard to stick to them. It might feel awkward in the first place and people might say, “We don´t need this!” And sometimes we feel discouraged by that. But if we manage to stick to them, they reveal themselves as some sort of miracle cure for our collaboration and product success. I would like to shed the light of a psychologist on why that is and pass some reasons on to you to persevere. We will also have plenty of time to talk the wonders you have encountered.

by Katrin E. Dreyer - Katrin Elise Dreyer is a business psychologist working to improve processes and team spirit as a Producer at Zalando. Before she went into working with teams at Zalando she was a product owner and later a scrum master at immobilenscout24.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on  http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: Stair 6, 5th floor. You will find some signs.
name: Learners' Meetup: The 7 wonders of Agile development

description:
If you are excited about web technologies, software or tech, you might have toyed with the thought of making your passion your profession and become a developer yourself! At this point of your journey you might ask yourself many questions around the profession, including "Is this the right job for my skill set and previous experience?" "What do I have to do to get my first job as a developer?" "How is it like to go freelance and which things do I have to take care of to do consulting?" "What's my best bet to advance from an internship / junior position to a more senior position?" and many more.

You are not alone with these questions and we figured it would be great to create a space for asking these. 

Therefore we'd like to invite you to a question & answer round on being or becoming a software developer at the co.up coworking space on next Thursday, June 1st starting from 7:15pm. 

Our panel of experienced software developers will answer your questions:

Our panelists:

Yulia (@ioctaptceb) is an accomplished developer and responsible for the development of developer tools at Mozilla

Lucie (@Autofocus) is an experienced front-end developer working at Cobot

Stefan(@Autarc) is a developer with lots of experience on both sides of the web stack

Giorgia(@designbygio) is a front-end developer with a strong design background working at Civey

Martin(@xmartin) is a well-versed front-end developer and mentor at Opentechschool Berlin

Our lightning talk speaker:

Ola(@misprintedtype) is an experienced and community-driven developer who will talk about her career path and her work at Mozilla

Make sure to RSVP to save your free seat or to cancel your reservation if you can't join to give others who are interested in this event the chance to attend.

Looking forward to see you there!
name: Career Night - Q&A on be(com)ing a professional software developer

description:
Learners' Meetup: Naming Things

CHANGE OF VENUE! For this meetup we will be at bitcrowd, not Co-up. Wheel chair users please call +4916094810972 to send the elevator down. Toilets are not wheelchair friendly.

A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) Naming Things

Code is meant to be read by people much more than by computers. When we write code, we should have the reader in mind.
You might have heard "There are two hard things in computer science: Cache invalidation, naming things and off-by-one errors". There is some truth to that. But with a few simple guidelines in mind you can make your life as someone who has to do with software development much easier.
The talk will start out by illustrating why it’s good to name things well. It will then tell you a little bit about how to inform the reader of your code about what is hidden behind variable, class and method names.
By the end of the talk, you should find naming a lot easier for many common cases.

by Martin Meyerhoff - Martin Meyerhoff is a political scientist, ruby developer and CEO of a company that works with the open source e-commerce framework Solidus.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

We usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: Stair 6, 5th floor. There will be signs. Wheel chair users please call +4916094810972 to send the elevator down. Toilets are not wheelchair friendly.

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Rachel Uwa 
rachel@opentechschool.org 
+49 151 7537 4602 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 151 7537 4602

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! You don't have to be a coder yourself 😃

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
We do our best to create a welcoming environment for people of all genders, and this takes more than just words. Please help us keep our community diverse by thinking of a female friend who could enjoy this meetup, and inviting them to join... seriously, just stop reading and do it 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 70070572 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Ratkaisu by Abe Pazos.

We'd love to feature your work on the cover for the next Stammtisch! Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.

Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! You don't have to be a coder yourself 😃

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
We do our best to create a welcoming environment for people of all genders, and this takes more than just words. Please help us keep our community diverse by thinking of a female friend who could enjoy this meetup, and inviting them to join... seriously, just stop reading and do it 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 70070572 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Raphaël de Courville.

We'd love to feature your work on the cover for the next Stammtisch! Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :)

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) Unicode, a 💌

A short introduction into text encoding, specifically Unicode, aimed at beginners.

Unicode is one of the things that can make you laugh and cry at the same time: it tries to put a (rather) unified system on top of one of the oldest cultural techniques we have: writing. I'd like to discuss Unicode in its context: why it came to be, how it works and what its advantages and flaws are.

You will leave this talk with the most important basics about Unicode: when to care about it, what and what not to care about and basic vocabulary to competently speak about it. 

by Florian Gilcher - Florian Gilcher is an active Rubyist and Rustacean. He runs conferences and meetups, such as the eurucamp, the RustFest and the Rust Hack & Learn in Berlin. During work hours, he mostly works on search, which is why he handles text a lot.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

Afterwards we usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: There will be signs in the yard. If you need to use the elevator bring a phone to call the number on the signs. Unfortunately the toilets are not wheelchair accessible.
name: Learners' Meetup: Unicode, a 💌

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Raphaël de Courville 
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com 
+49 176 700 70572

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 176 700 70572

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We are in the 3rd or 5th floor, please check the signs
name: Python Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) What does a Product Manager do?

What does a Product Manager do? Ask different people and you will get different answers. The Product Manager is a "jack of all trades" (someone who does... well, everything). Some call them the "mini-CEO". Or the "defender of the customer". So... what does a Product Manager actually do? And why do we need them? Shaun found his own answer to this question. He will attempt to clear up the confusion by sharing his story as a Product Manager, the lessons he learnt along the way, and how he now thinks differently about his job, 5 years on.

by Shaun Russell -Shaun is a Product Manager at Outfittery, a personal shopping service based in Berlin. His previous experience includes London-based fashion retailer Lyst, and Adthena, a search intelligence tool.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

Afterwards we usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on http://discourse.opentechschool.org/

description:
The Creative Code Stammtisch is an open conversation between artists, makers, designers, coders, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! You don't have to be a coder yourself 😃

WHAT SHOULD I EXPECT?
There is a time for people to present something if they want to, followed by informal discussions. Every topic is fair game, from net art to computational design and interactive installations all the way to wearable electronics and generative literature... It's a whole evening packed with fun, inspiration and human connection.

Join us on Friday and see for yourself, ask questions if you want, contribute with your comments and maybe show a project you're working on. We're looking forward to meet you all!

Note that this event is NOT just for coders! If you like art and/or technology, you will certainly enjoy yourself, and perhaps even learn something!

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY
We do our best to create a welcoming environment for people of all genders, and this takes more than just words. Please help us keep our community diverse by thinking of a female friend who could enjoy this meetup, and inviting them to join... seriously, just stop reading and do it 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events.

SAFE SPACE POLICY
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct: 
</a><a href="http://berlincodeofconduct.org/">berlincodeofconduct.org
Please read and make sure you agree with its content.

IS THE PLACE WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE? 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN?
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :) 

CONTACT 
Raphaël de Courville  
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com  
+49 (0) 176 70070572 

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: @creativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8  
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 

- - -

The featured artwork of the month is by Abe Pazos.

We'd love to feature your work on the cover for the next Stammtisch! Please send an image at team.ccberlin@gmail.com.
how_to_find_us: Enter through one of the two gates, then walk to the back of the compound. Spot the door across from the white mailboxes and ring at "co-up".

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) Intro to Databases and SQL

Relational databases provide reliable and efficient data storage since several decades. Though NoSQL technologies are getting widely used in some applications recently and might be a great choice, having relational database management systems and SQL in the tool-box still remains a must for any senior developer, data engineer or data scientist. In this talk, I will start with the philosophical question how we transfer data to knowledge and give a short introduction or what relational and no-SQL databases actually are.

by Ilya Vladimirskiy - Ilya studied mathematics in Moscow, did computer science research in Marburg and worked as a database developer, data engineer, and consultant. He currently works as product owner at Smartfrog, an IoT startup based in Berlin. His previous experience includes fashion platform Zalando and match-making service eDarling.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

Afterwards we usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: There will be signs in the yard. If you need to use the elevator bring a phone to call the number on the signs. Unfortunately the toilets are not wheelchair accessible.
name: Learners' Meetup: Intro to Databases and SQL

description:
This is all about building things in the browser: HTML, CSS and lots of JavaScript.

We are a friendly group that meets every Wednesday to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop (otherwise we can provide one for you) and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or would love to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an experienced expert, we want to learn from each other.

Doors open latest at 19:30h, introduction round at 20:00h.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials. We're here to help with that, too. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

JavaScript for Beginners 1 | JavaScript for Beginners 2 | Intro to HTML/CSS

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)

You're also welcome to join our chat on Gitter.

We do have a code of conduct.
how_to_find_us: 5th floor - If the gate is closed try the small one. Get inside of the backyard and than turn left (block in the middle)
name: Web Frontend Co-Learning

description:
***
Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we’ll contact you. 

***

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 5-6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. Please bring your laptop or let us know in advance if you can't bring one, we have a very limited number of laptops available.

Agenda for Sunday: 

10:30 Doors open

11:00-11:15 Welcome

11:15-13:00 Coding in groups

13:00-14:00 Lunch Break (there are many food options in the area, or you can bring your own)

14:00-14:20 Lightning Talks

14:20-16:30 Coding in groups

16:30-17:00 Demos

17:00-17:30 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website: https://cssclass.es

Learning Materials: cssclass.es/materials
Slack channel: slack.cssclass.es

***

Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we'll contact you.

***
name: CSSclasses

description:
We are back! After a long pause we are restarting the Go Co-Learning. 

Update: Please note that the location has changed!

The Go Co-Learning group is a biweekly-ish meetup for everyone interested in learning Go/Golang.

We have no fixed agenda and there are no talks or lectures. Instead we work on tutorials or projects and help each other when we get stuck. If you have no previous experience, we can suggest learning material. We meet on (almost) every first and third Tuesday of the month.

Make sure to bring a laptop! If you don't have access to one, message one of the organisers a few days in advance. We can probably bring one from the OpenTechSchool stash. :)
how_to_find_us: Go to the parking lot and turn towards the building on the right side. Enter through the first door behind the gatekeepers house (Pfoertnerhaus). It's on the top floor on the right side.

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We are in the 3rd or 5th floor, please check the signs
name: Python Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - rustfmt https://github.com/rust-lang-nursery/rustfmt/issues

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Raphaël de Courville 
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com 
+49 176 700 70572

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 176 700 70572

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) How do I become a Product Manager?

How does one become a Product Manager? Some say the technical background is a must, some say you should have solid experience at least in some aspects of business process… And once you get into the product game, how do you master it? Emilie will talk about her experience transitioning from business to product role and will share some tricks that helped her during this process. 

by Emilie Lindström - Emilie is a Product Manager at Outfittery, a personal shopping service based in Berlin. Her previous experiences include various roles in personnel development, process quality assurance, and business development.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

Afterwards we usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on http://discourse.opentechschool.org/

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• Due to limited seats of 20 (16 attendees & 4 organizers), we have created a separate list for coaches. If you are a coach, organizer or want to help the learners, please register per each event for the separate coaches list or post your name and specialty in this forum thread.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

- Install Rust (duh) https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html. If you prefer a version-manager-like tool try https://rustup.rs (highly recommended!)

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/stable/book/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings

- Two projects with great first bugs:

  - Clippy! https://github.com/Manishearth/rust-clippy

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Raphaël de Courville 
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com 
+49 176 700 70572

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 176 700 70572

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up

description:
***
Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we’ll contact you. 

***

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike. Around 5-6pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. Please bring your laptop or let us know in advance if you can't bring one, we have a very limited number of laptops available.

Agenda for Sunday: 

10:30 Doors open

11:00-11:15 Welcome

11:15-13:00 Coding in groups

13:00-14:00 Lunch Break (there are many food options in the area, or you can bring your own)

14:00-14:20 Lightning Talks

14:20-16:30 Coding in groups

16:30-17:00 Demos

17:00-17:30 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website: https://cssclass.es

Learning Materials: cssclass.es/materials
Slack channel: slack.cssclass.es

***

Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form and we'll contact you.

***

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) *What’s going on? Monitoring, Instrumentation and Metrics*

When running software one is often a bit clueless what is actually happening. Say the computer’s CPUs are at 80%: Is something broken and slowing down other parts? Or is everything running smoothly and we are just making good use of resources?
And what are your users actually doing? With metrics and instrumentation we can investigate how our software and systems behave while they run.
In this introduction you will be taught a few basics of monitoring, get an idea of what can be done with it and see some examples of a monitoring toolkit called Prometheus.

by *Nicolai von Neudeck* - Nicolai does DevOps for a living, studied cultural anthropology (californian computing, science and technology studies, populism, comics, antisemitism) and likes recumbent bicycles.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

Afterwards we usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: There will be signs in the yard. If you need to use the elevator bring a phone to call the number on the signs. Unfortunately the toilets are not wheelchair accessible.
name: Learners' Meetup: What's going on? Intro to  Monitoring & Metrics

description:
• What we'll do
Register and attend if you want to meet up like minded people and dive into a nodeschool workshop. There are workshops available for every skill level -- from JS beginners all the way to experienced node programmers. NodeSchool is a community driven, open source educational platform that teaches various node.js and JavaScript skills in an interactive, self-guided format.

There will be drinks and food provided by Mozilla :)

There is no fixed schedule, but we usually learn and hack until 9.00 pm

See you there!

• What to bring
Bring your laptop

• Important to know
NodeSchool strives to be a welcoming and safe event for all attendees. Attendees have to follow the Code of Conduct: https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin/blob/master/codeofconduct.md
how_to_find_us: Enter through the door marked "Treppenhaus C" , and go up to the 3th floor.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Raphaël de Courville 
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com 
+49 176 700 70572

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 176 700 70572

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
The Go Co-Learning group is a biweekly-ish meetup for everyone interested in learning Go/Golang.

We have no fixed agenda and there are no talks or lectures. Instead we work on tutorials or projects and help each other when we get stuck. If you have no previous experience, we can suggest learning material. We meet on (almost) every first and third Tuesday of the month.

Make sure to bring a laptop! If you don't have access to one, message one of the organisers a few days in advance. We can bring one from the OpenTechSchool stash. :)

description:
We are a friendly group of data enthusiasts who are going to meet every other Thursday to learn together.

This time we are at the Co.up community event space. Find more information here: http://co-up.de/about.html

"Data science" might be broadly defined as the collection and analysis of data, as well as the communication of any resulting insights. To this end, data scientists use a broad range of tools and methods: R, Python, databases, statistics, machine learning… The list goes on. No topic is off limits in our group, and every skill level is welcome, so come and learn from others, and share your own experience!

This is a Co-Learning group, so no presentations or lessons are planned, but we might occasionally put something together if there's enough interest.

The rules: Bring your own laptop and respect the code of conduct: http://www.opentechschool.org/code-of-conduct/.

If you don't have a project to work on, or if you're otherwise unsure how to get started, check out our list of tutorials and resources and our list of learning projects:

https://github.com/ellenkoenig/datascience-co-learning
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1KTZPbi7lsZe1EFaXpGoFWipBNSikC2IIhmct6zRvDNg/edit?usp=sharing

Contact the organizers or coaches with any questions.

We speak English and German.

See you there!
how_to_find_us: Co.up community event space, 5th floor. The entrance is a bit hidden in the second backyard. Look for our signs or signs for "Clue" (they are in the same building).
