description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

description:
A friendly meetup of learners of all levels with an easy-to-understand talk on tech, learning or hacking, followed by discussions in small groups to connect and find answers to our tech-related questions. For the agenda, click on „Read more“.

Talk (ca. 20 mins) *How to do an abstraction layer: How and why to solve problems with concepts, not just code.*

Writing code is fun, but we're never "just" writing code. When we write code, we are also solving a problem. This talk is about how to make your code reflect the concepts you are using to solve your problem, i.e. how to do an 'abstraction layer.' When you succeed at writing an abstraction layer, your code becomes simpler and easier to read.

by *Christian Clampitt* - Christian was born in Denver, Colorado USA. He is a developer at Liefery and enjoys coding and painting.

A mini barcamp! (ca. 40 mins)

Anyone is invited to propose a topic they want to discuss or get help with and we organise ourselves into groups or pairs. At the end we share what we discussed.

Afterwards we usually continue our discussions with a drink in a nearby bar. Looking forward to see you!

Ideas/questions? Reach out to us on http://discourse.opentechschool.org/
how_to_find_us: There will be signs! Cross the first courtyard and enter the glass door on the left side (it does not say Searchmetrics on that door). We are on the first floor behind a big metal door. Please contact us in advance for wheelchair accessibility.
name: Learners' Meetup: How to do an abstraction layer

description:
This is all about building things in the browser: HTML, CSS and lots of JavaScript.

We are a friendly group that meets every Wednesday to learn together and work on our projects. Bring your laptop (otherwise we can provide one for you) and your challenges and questions. There's always someone around that is happy to help you or would love to get some help. No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an experienced expert, we want to learn from each other.

Doors open latest at 19:30h, introduction round at 20:00h.

Usually there is no talks or lessons planned but we can come up with something together if there's interest.

If you don't have a project to work on or don't know where to start it's also a good idea to do some online classes or tutorials. We're here to help with that, too. For example check out some of our OpenTechSchool workshop material:

JavaScript for Beginners 1 (http://opentechschool.github.io/js-beginners-1/) | JavaScript for Beginners 2 (http://opentechschool.github.io/js-beginners-2/) | Intro to HTML/CSS (http://cssclass.es/materials/)

We speak German and English, sometimes even Italian, and of course code. Just come by and check it out! Oh, and bring some snacks, maybe ;)

You're also welcome to join our chat on Gitter (https://gitter.im/OpenTechSchool/BLN-WFColearning).

We do have a code of conduct (http://www.opentechschool.org/code-of-conduct/).
how_to_find_us: The entrance is a bit hidden in the second backyard. Look for our signs or "Clue" signs (they are next to Co.Up). 5th floor.
name: Web Frontend Co-Learning

description:
***
Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1t3YNYCmuuF8x5NfEd6qfABNWPBqiSJPWeNFLSoD2vIg) and we’ll contact you.

***

The day will include an optional workshop for beginners (and anyone who feels like refreshing their basics), as well as free hacking and collaborating for experts and newbies alike.
Plus, this time we'll offer a workshop on the basics of layouting with flexbox & grid.

Around 3.30pm, we’ll wrap up and everyone is invited to demo their achievements. Please bring your laptop or let us know in advance if you can't bring one, we have a very limited number of laptops available.

Agenda for Sunday:

10:30 Doors open

11:00-11:15 Welcome

11:15-13:00 Coding in groups

13:00-14:00 Lunch Break (there are many food options in the area, or you can bring your own)

14:00-15:30 Coding in groups

15:30-15:50 Demos

15:50-16:00 Wrap up

An event around CSS… really?

Yes! We believe that CSS is one of the quickest and most fun ways to understand how websites are built and get your hands into coding. And that doesn’t mean CSS is for beginners only: Just check out the stunning experiments on Codepen.io. Or see what leading developers are discussing at events like CSSconf EU to get inspired and see how far you can take the language.

Who is organizing this?

The volunteer teams behind CSSconf EU and OpenTechSchool. We have experience in teaching, organizing workshops and community events, and our motivation is to share knowledge and passion for building fun and beautiful things for the web. We subscribe to the core values of OpenTechSchool and are committed to create a safe and encouraging space for learners and coaches.

Check out our website: https://cssclass.es

Learning Materials: cssclass.es/materials (https://cssclass.es/materials/)
Slack channel: http://slack.cssclass.es

***

Are you interested in coaching? Great! Please fill in this form (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1t3YNYCmuuF8x5NfEd6qfABNWPBqiSJPWeNFLSoD2vIg) and we'll contact you.

***
how_to_find_us: The entrance is a bit hidden in the second backyard. Look for our signs or "Clue" signs (they are next to Co.Up). 3rd floor.
name: CSSclasses

description:
ABOUT:

The meet-up is all about Ruby and Rails (but also about all the other things you can do with Ruby).

We are a friendly group that meets every other monday at seven o'clock to learn together and work on our projects. All you need is to bring your laptop - additional power strips and some snacks are also welcome.

No matter if you are an absolute beginner or an expert, we want to learn from each other. Bring along your personal project or a specific challenge. There's always someone around to help you or someone who'll be happy about you helping them.

Sometimes, we have some short talks on a particular feature of the Ruby language geared towards beginners.

We speak German and English, and of course code. Just come by and check it out!

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread (http://discourse.opentechschool.org/t/ruby-co-learning-resources) that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Ruby Co-Learning

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org. Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We are in the 3rd or 5th floor, please check the signs
name: Python Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html .

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings
how_to_find_us: Please use Entrance 4, which is at the very back if you come from Lohmühlenstraße, past the main entrance.
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
We are a friendly group of data enthusiasts who are going to meet every other Thursday to learn together.

We meet at the Co.up community event space. Find more information here: http://co-up.de/about.html

"Data science" might be broadly defined as the collection and analysis of data, as well as the communication of any resulting insights. To this end, data scientists use a broad range of tools and methods: R, Python, databases, statistics, machine learning… The list goes on. No topic is off limits in our group, and every skill level is welcome, so come and learn from others, and share your own experience!

This is a Co-Learning group, so no presentations or lessons are planned, but we might occasionally put something together if there's enough interest.

The rules: Bring your own laptop and respect the code of conduct: http://www.opentechschool.org/code-of-conduct/.

If you don't have a project to work on, or if you're otherwise unsure how to get started, check out our list of tutorials and resources and our list of learning projects:

https://github.com/ellenkoenig/datascience-co-learning
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1KTZPbi7lsZe1EFaXpGoFWipBNSikC2IIhmct6zRvDNg/edit?usp=sharing

Contact the organizers or coaches with any questions.

We speak English and German.

See you there!
how_to_find_us: 3rd or 5th floor, depending on the availability -> follow the Open Tech School signs!
name: Data Science Co-Learning

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Raphaël de Courville 
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com 
+49 176 700 70572

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 176 700 70572

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
• What we'll do
Register and attend if you want to meet up like minded people and dive into a nodeschool workshop. There are workshops available for every skill level -- from JS beginners all the way to experienced node programmers. NodeSchool is a community driven, open source educational platform that teaches various node.js and JavaScript skills in an interactive, self-guided format.

There will be drinks provided by Mozilla :)

There is no fixed schedule, but we usually learn and hack until 9.00 pm

See you there!

• What to bring
Bring your laptop

• Important to know
NodeSchool strives to be a welcoming and safe event for all attendees. Attendees have to follow the Code of Conduct: https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin/blob/master/codeofconduct.md
how_to_find_us: Enter through the door marked "Treppenhaus C" , and go up to the 3th floor.

description:
We learn server side programming together! Want to setup a blog using Wordpress? Program your first Django or Rails app? Install an audio server on a Raspberry Pi? Improve your testing skills?

Whether your language of choice is Ruby, Python, Go (?) or something entirely different, come along. There will be coaches present who can help you with Ruby, Python, PHP and Go. If we don’t know something, let’s figure it out together!

This group is open to total beginners in programming as well as to more experienced programmers who want to get their feet wet in another language or explore new topics.

If possible, bring your own laptop. We have some computers available, but they are a bit slow. Snacks are also very welcome!

Our learning materials are available under https://learn.opentechschool.org.

We run a short intro round at the beginning of the meetup where everyone can say what their project is or how they can help others.

We speak German and English.

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread (http://discourse.opentechschool.org/t/ruby-co-learning-resources) that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Server-Side Co-Learning

description:
This year OpenTechSchool Foundation will turn 5 years old and we want to celebrate this with all of you!

During these years OpenTechSchool grown, develop and change becoming bigger and stronger. This wasn't possible without the help of so many people, in different part of the world.
So this party is for all of you, to thank you for the time invest in learning, sharing, coaching, organising and supporting this great community which aim to give equal opportunity to whoever is interested in IT related topics.

Schedule:
_ Door open at 7.30pm
_ 8.00pm - 21.40pm OTS review: The past, the present and the future
_ 21.45pm - 1am Drinks and socialising

The event is free of charge, just come and enjoy.
There will be food, drinks and some interesting interactive games :)
Of course you can come with your family, partner, friends, ... But please RSVP for all of them so we know how many people will be there and we can organise the party even better.

Are you new to OTS?
This event is done to thank all the people that already have put time (even if little) in make our community better.
Still, if you are completely new to OpenTechSchool we are happy to see you there and get to know you.
Just bear in mind there will be no technical talks, no co-learning or coaching. But lot of nice and interesting people to get to know :)

More Info about OpenTechSchool:
http://www.opentechschool.org/

Please respect other and our code of conduct: http://www.opentechschool.org/code-of-conduct/
name: OpenTechSchool 5 years b-day bash

description:
• What we'll do
Register and attend if you want to meet up like minded people and dive into a nodeschool workshop. There are workshops available for every skill level -- from JS beginners all the way to experienced node programmers. NodeSchool is a community driven, open source educational platform that teaches various node.js and JavaScript skills in an interactive, self-guided format.

There will be drinks provided by Mozilla :)

There is no fixed schedule, but we usually learn and hack until 9.00 pm

See you there!

• What to bring
Bring your laptop

• Important to know
NodeSchool strives to be a welcoming and safe event for all attendees. Attendees have to follow the Code of Conduct: https://github.com/nodeschool/berlin/blob/master/codeofconduct.md
how_to_find_us: Enter through the door marked "Treppenhaus C" , and go up to the 3th floor.

description:
The Creative Code Jam is a monthly gathering of artists, makers, designers, illustrators, coders, musicians, performers, learners and anyone interested in the use of computing skills for artistic expression. The event is free and open to all, regardless of age, origin, gender or experience. The jam is an opportunity to meet likeminded people and get creative together in a relaxed and safe environment. Beginners and first-timers should feel especially welcome! 

SO WHAT'S GOING ON EXACTLY? 
Participants are encouraged to team up and produce new work together. Our focus is on collaboration between disciplines, spontaneity and experimentation. 

We sometimes propose exercises that foster creativity, collaboration as well as an exchange of skills between attendees. 

The format is open and we like to keep it experimental so if you want to suggest an activity, please let us know! If it fits, we will make it happen :) 

A NOTE ON DIVERSITY  
Our best meetups have also been the most diverse. This is no coincidence. If each of us took the step to invite one female friend to join, everyone involved would benefit. We kindly ask you to pause for a minute and think who that friend could be... seriously, just stop reading and do it! 🙈 

This invitation extends, of course, to members of all groups that are usually underrepresented at art & tech events. 

SAFE SPACE POLICY 
We support the Berlin Code of Conduct:  
https://rubyberlin.github.io/code-of-conduct/ 
Please make sure you agree with its content.

</a>

ACCESSIBILITY 
Co.up rooms are located on the third and fifth floor, so we will happily provide assistance with the elevator to those who need it. Please let us know how we can make the space more accessible and your visit more comfortable!

DO I NEED TO SPEAK GERMAN? 
We speak mostly English so international guests are more than welcome! Our team also speaks French, Italian, Spanish, Finnish and German... Language availability may vary depending on which organizers are present :)

CONTACT  
Raphaël de Courville 
raphael.de.courville@gmail.com 
+49 176 700 70572

Or shout random words at us on Twitter: <a href="http://twitter.com/creativecodeBLN">@CreativeCodeBLN

WHERE IS IT? 
Co-up Coworking space Adalbertstr. 7-8 
(back of the compound, to the left, across from white mailboxes) 
The gate is closed? Call: +49 176 700 70572

Note: Our friends at Co.up coworking are letting us use their space for free. HOW COOL IS THAT? ⸝(*⌒ω⌒*)ﾉ♥ You can thank them by buying one of their 2€ drinks.
how_to_find_us: Enter one of the two gates then walk to the back of the compound. In the underpass, look for the door across from white mailboxes and ring at co.up
name: Creative Code Jam

description:
We learn server side programming together! Want to setup a blog using Wordpress? Program your first Django or Rails app? Install an audio server on a Raspberry Pi? Improve your testing skills?

Whether your language of choice is Ruby, Python, Go (?) or something entirely different, come along. There will be coaches present who can help you with Ruby, Python, PHP and Go. If we don’t know something, let’s figure it out together!

This group is open to total beginners in programming as well as to more experienced programmers who want to get their feet wet in another language or explore new topics.

If possible, bring your own laptop. We have some computers available, but they are a bit slow. Snacks are also very welcome!

Our learning materials are available under https://learn.opentechschool.org.

We run a short intro round at the beginning of the meetup where everyone can say what their project is or how they can help others.

We speak German and English.

IMPORTANT NOTES & LINKS:

• The RSVP-function will be open 7 days before a meetup takes place.

• If you don't have a project to work on, it is often a good idea to do a tutorial or some exercises. See our discourse thread (http://discourse.opentechschool.org/t/ruby-co-learning-resources) that includes our favorites (and add your own).
name: Server-Side Co-Learning

description:
This is a work group of python learners, meeting up every other week to continue learning on python. As always there will be experienced Python Coaches around but we also just learn from each other. You can just check the RSVP-List for people tagged "python coach" and feel free to contact any of them directly at the event.

This group is open to total beginners in programming, who want to learn python, as well as to people, who are further or just have specific questions and/or need help with python related topics. Please don't forget to bring your own laptop.

The OpenTechSchool Python Coaches (https://groups.google.com/a/opentechschool.org/forum/?fromgroups#!forum/coaches.python) release all their learning material at learn.opentechschool.org (http://learn.opentechschool.org/). Feel free to take a look.
how_to_find_us: We will be on the Third Floor
name: Python And Ruby Co-Learning

description:
Rust is a new systems programming language developed by Mozilla.

Let's meet for open hacking and (co)-learning in our bi-weekly learning group!

Everyone is welcome. Rusties of all skill levels meet and hack on cool Rust stuff. Please bring a computer (if available) or tell us if you need one, we can provide you with a machine.

Never written a single line of Rust, but interested in the language? Don't worry, most of us are just starting off. There are people around to get you set up and going.

Already have a project? Just hack on it or find others interested in contributing. If you have something working, you can put it on the big screen and show everyone.

Don't have a project yet? There are lots of ideas and cool projects floating around that you can work on!

Here are some ideas if you don't know what to hack on:

- Install Rust https://www.rust-lang.org/downloads.html .

- Read the Rust book https://doc.rust-lang.org/

- Complete the Rustlings (a great beginners course!) https://github.com/carols10cents/rustlings
name: Rust Hack and Learn

description:
We are a friendly group of data enthusiasts who are going to meet every other Thursday to learn together.

We meet at the Co.up community event space. Find more information here: http://co-up.de/about.html

We start with our introductory round at 7:30, so please be there before.

"Data science" might be broadly defined as the collection and analysis of data, as well as the communication of any resulting insights. To this end, data scientists use a broad range of tools and methods: R, Python, databases, statistics, machine learning… The list goes on. No topic is off limits in our group, and every skill level is welcome, so come and learn from others, and share your own experience!

This is a Co-Learning group, so no presentations or lessons are planned, but we might occasionally put something together if there's enough interest.

The rules: Bring your own laptop and respect the code of conduct → http://www.opentechschool.org/code-of-conduct/.
